<P class="p297 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">3.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">The institutions shall count daily overshootings on the basis of </SPAN><NOBR>back-testing</NOBR> on hypothetical and actual changes in the portfolio's value. An overshooting is a <NOBR>one-day</NOBR> change in the portfolio's value that exceeds the related <NOBR>one-day</NOBR> <NOBR>value-at-risk</NOBR> number generated by the institution's model. For the purpose of determining the addend the number of overshootings shall be assessed at least quarterly and shall be equal to the higher of the number of overshootings under hypothetical and actual changes in the value of the portfolio.</P>
<P class="p298 ft1"><NOBR>Back-testing</NOBR> on hypothetical changes in the portfolio's value shall be based on a comparison between the portfolio's <NOBR>end-of-day</NOBR> value and, assuming unchanged positions, its value at the end of the subsequent day.</P>
<P class="p24 ft1"><NOBR>Back-testing</NOBR> on actual changes in the portfolio's value shall be based on a comparison between the portfolio's <NOBR>end-of-day</NOBR> value and its actual value at the end of the subsequent day excluding fees, commissions, and net interest income.</P>
<P class="p18 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">4.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">The competent authorities may in individual cases limit the addend to that resulting from overshootings under hypothetical changes, where the number of overshootings under actual changes does not result from deficiencies in the internal model.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p18 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">5.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">In order to allow competent authorities to monitor the appropriateness of the multiplication factors on an ongoing basis, institutions shall notify promptly, and in any case no later than within five working days, the competent authorities of overshootings that result form their </SPAN><NOBR>back-testing</NOBR> programme.</P>
<P class="p44 ft8">Article 356</P>
<P class="p96 ft8">Requirements on risk measurement</P>
<P class="p16 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">1.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">Any internal model used to calculate capital requirements for position risk, foreign exchange risk, commodities risk and any internal model for correlation trading shall meet all of the following requirements:</SPAN></P>
<P class="p191 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(a)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft12">the model shall capture accurately all material price risks;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p39 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(b)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft11">the model shall capture a sufficient number of risk factors, depending on the level of activity of the institution in the respective markets. The institution shall at least</SPAN></P>
<P class="p247 ft1">45</P>
</DIV>
<DIV id="page_47">


<P class="p117 ft1">incorporate those risk factors in its model that are incorporated into its pricing model. The <NOBR>risk-measurement</NOBR> model shall capture nonlinearities for options and other products as well as correlation risk and basis risk. Where proxies for risk factors are used they shall show a good track record for the actual position held.</P>
<P class="p18 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">2.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">Any internal model used to calculate capital requirements for position risk, foreign exchange risk or commodities risk shall meet all of the following requirements:</SPAN></P>
<P class="p21 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(a)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft12">the model shall incorporate a set of risk factors corresponding to the interest rates in each currency in which the institution has interest rate sensitive on- or </SPAN><NOBR>off-balance</NOBR> sheet positions. The institution shall model the yield curves using one of the generally accepted approaches. For material exposures to <NOBR>interest-rate</NOBR> risk in the major currencies and markets, the yield curve shall be divided into a minimum of six maturity segments, to capture the variations of volatility of rates along the yield curve. The model shall also capture the risk of less than perfectly correlated movements between different yield curves;</P>
<P class="p162 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(b)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft11">the model shall incorporate risk factors corresponding to gold and to the individual foreign currencies in which the institution's positions are denominated. For CIUs the actual foreign exchange positions of the CIU shall be taken into account. Institutions may rely on third party reporting of the foreign exchange position of the CIU, where the correctness of this report is adequately ensured. If an institution is not aware of the foreign exchange positions of a CIU, this position shall be carved out and treated in accordance with Article 342(3);</SPAN></P>
<P class="p299 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(c)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft12">the model shall use a separate risk factor at least for each of the equity markets in which the institution holds significant positions;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p35 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(d)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft11">the model shall use a separate risk factor at least for each commodity in which the institution holds significant positions. The model must also capture the risk of less than perfectly correlated movements between similar, but not identical, commodities and the exposure to changes in forward prices arising from maturity mismatches. It shall also take account of market characteristics, notably delivery dates and the scope provided to traders to close out positions;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p109 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(e)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft12">the institution's internal model shall conservatively assess the risk arising from less liquid positions and positions with limited price transparency under realistic market scenarios. In addition, the internal model shall meet minimum data standards. Proxies shall be appropriately conservative and shall be used only where available data is insufficient or is not reflective of the true volatility of a position or portfolio.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p119 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">3.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">Institutions may, in any internal model used for purposes of this Chapter, use empirical correlations within risk categories and across risk categories only if the institution's approach for measuring correlations is sound and implemented with integrity.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p300 ft1">46</P>
</DIV>
<DIV id="page_48">


<P class="p26 ft8">Article 357</P>
<P class="p260 ft8">Qualitative requirements</P>
<P class="p33 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">1.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">Any internal model used for purposes of this Chapter shall be conceptually sound and implemented with integrity and, in particular, all of the following qualitative requirements shall be met:</SPAN></P>
<P class="p34 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(a)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft12">any internal model used to calculate capital requirements for position risk, foreign exchange risk or commodities risk is shall be closely integrated into the daily risk- management process of the institution and serve as the basis for reporting risk exposures to senior management;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p34 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(b)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft11">the institution shall have a risk control unit that is independent from business trading units and reports directly to senior management. The unit shall be responsible for designing and implementing any internal model used for purposes of this Chapter. The unit shall conduct the initial and </SPAN><NOBR>on-going</NOBR> validation of any internal model used for purposes of this Chapter. The unit shall produce and analyse daily reports on the output of any internal model used for calculating capital requirements for position risk, foreign exchange risk and commodities risk, and on the appropriate measures to be taken in terms of trading limits;</P>
<P class="p162 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(c)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft12">the institution's management body and senior management shall be actively involved in the </SPAN><NOBR>risk-control</NOBR> process and the daily reports produced by the <NOBR>risk-control</NOBR> unit are reviewed by a level of management with sufficient authority to enforce both reductions of positions taken by individual traders as well as in the institution's overall risk exposure;</P>
<P class="p109 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(d)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft11">the institution shall have sufficient numbers of staff skilled in the use of sophisticated internal models, and including the ones used for purposes of this Chapter, in the trading, </SPAN><NOBR>risk-control,</NOBR> audit and <NOBR>back-office</NOBR> areas;</P>
<P class="p35 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(e)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft12">the institution shall have established procedures for monitoring and ensuring compliance with a documented set of internal policies and controls concerning the overall operation of its internal models, and including the ones used for purposes of this Chapter;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p35 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(f)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft30">any internal model used for purposes of this Chapter shall have a proven track record of reasonable accuracy in measuring risks;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p21 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(g)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft11">the institution shall frequently conduct a rigorous programme of stress testing, including reverse stress tests, which encompasses any internal model used for purposes of this Chapter and the results of these stress tests shall be reviewed by senior management and reflected in the policies and limits it sets. This process shall particularly address illiquidity of markets in stressed market conditions, concentration risk, one way markets, event and </SPAN><NOBR>jump-to-default</NOBR> risks, <NOBR>non-linearity</NOBR> of products, deep <NOBR>out-of-the-money</NOBR> positions, positions subject to the gapping of prices and other risks that may not be captured appropriately in the internal models. The shocks applied shall reflect the nature of the portfolios and the time it could take to hedge out or manage risks under severe market conditions;</P>
<P class="p301 ft1">47</P>
</DIV>
<DIV id="page_49">


<P class="p37 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(h)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft11">the institution shall conduct, as part of its regular internal auditing process, an independent review of its internal models, and including the ones used for purposes of this Chapter.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p114 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">2.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">The review referred to in point (h) of the first paragraph shall include both the activities of the business trading units and of the independent </SPAN><NOBR>risk-control</NOBR> unit. At least once a year, the institution shall conduct a review of its overall <NOBR>risk-management</NOBR> process. The review shall consider the following:</P>
<P class="p34 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(a)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft12">the adequacy of the documentation of the </SPAN><NOBR>risk-management</NOBR> system and process and the organisation of the <NOBR>risk-control</NOBR> unit;</P>
<P class="p21 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(b)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft11">the integration of risk measures into daily risk management and the integrity of the management information system;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p21 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(c)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft12">the process the institution employs for approving </SPAN><NOBR>risk-pricing</NOBR> models and valuation systems that are used by front and <NOBR>back-office</NOBR> personnel;</P>
<P class="p35 ft4"><SPAN class="ft1">(d)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft13">the scope of risks captured by the </SPAN><NOBR>risk-measurement</NOBR> model and the validation of any significant changes in the <NOBR>risk-measurement</NOBR> process;</P>
<P class="p22 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(e)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft12">the accuracy and completeness of position data, the accuracy and appropriateness of volatility and correlation assumptions, and the accuracy of valuation and risk sensitivity calculations;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p34 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(f)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft30">the verification process the institution employs to evaluate the consistency, timeliness and reliability of data sources used to run internal models, including the independence of such data sources;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p97 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(g)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft11">the verification process the institution uses to evaluate </SPAN><NOBR>back-testing</NOBR> that is conducted to assess the models' accuracy.</P>
<P class="p218 ft4"><SPAN class="ft1">3.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft17">As techniques and best practices evolve, institutions shall apply those new techniques and practices in any internal model used for purposes of this Chapter.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p220 ft8">Article 358</P>
<P class="p302 ft8">Internal Validation</P>
<P class="p33 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">1.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">Institutions shall have processes in place to ensure that all their internal models used for purposes of this Chapter have been adequately validated by suitably qualified parties independent of the development process to ensure that they are conceptually sound and adequately capture all material risks. The validation shall be conducted when the internal model is initially developed and when any significant changes are made to the internal model. The validation shall also be conducted on a periodic basis but especially where there have been any significant structural changes in the market or changes to the composition of the portfolio which might lead to the internal model no longer being adequate. As techniques and best practices for internal validation evolve, institutions shall apply these advances. Internal model validation shall not be limited to </SPAN><NOBR>back-testing,</NOBR> but shall, at a minimum, also include the following:</P>
<P class="p188 ft1">48</P>
</DIV>
<DIV id="page_50">


<P class="p37 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(a)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft12">tests to demonstrate that any assumptions made within the internal model are appropriate and do not underestimate or overestimate the risk;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p21 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(b)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft11">in addition to the regulatory </SPAN><NOBR>back-testing</NOBR> programmes, institutions shall carry out their own internal model validation tests, including <NOBR>back-testing,</NOBR> in relation to the risks and structures of their portfolios;</P>
<P class="p35 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(c)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft12">the use of hypothetical portfolios to ensure that the internal model is able to account for particular structural features that may arise, for example material basis risks and concentration risk.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p18 ft4"><SPAN class="ft1">2.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft17">The institution shall perform </SPAN><NOBR>back-testing</NOBR> on both actual and hypothetical changes in the portfolio's value.</P>
<P class="p303 ft33"><SPAN class="ft32">S</SPAN>ECTION <SPAN class="ft32">3</SPAN></P>
<P class="p304 ft33"><SPAN class="ft32">R</SPAN>EQUIREMENTS PARTICULAR TO SPECIFIC RISK MODELLING</P>
<P class="p141 ft8">Article 359</P>
<P class="p305 ft8">Requirements for modelling specific risk</P>
<P class="p238 ft1">An internal model used for calculating own funds requirements for specific risk and an internal model for correlation trading shall meet the following additional requirements:</P>
<P class="p107 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(a)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft59">it explains the historical price variation in the portfolio;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p107 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(b)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft31">it captures concentration in terms of magnitude and changes of composition of the portfolio;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p107 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(c)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft59">it is robust to an adverse environment;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p33 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(d)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft31">it is validated through </SPAN><NOBR>back-testing</NOBR> aimed at assessing whether specific risk is being accurately captured. If the institution performs such <NOBR>back-testing</NOBR> on the basis of relevant <NOBR>sub-portfolios,</NOBR> these must be chosen in a consistent manner;</P>
<P class="p18 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(e)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft31">it captures </SPAN><NOBR>name-related</NOBR> basis risk and shall in particular be sensitive to material idiosyncratic differences between similar but not identical positions;</P>
<P class="p107 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(f)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft34">it captures event risk.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p31 ft8">Article 360</P>
<P class="p306 ft8">Exclusions from specific risk models</P>
<P class="p33 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">1.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">An institution may choose to exclude from the calculation of its specific risk own funds requirement using an internal model those positions for which it fulfils an own funds requirement for specific risk in accordance with point (c) of Article 353.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p218 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">2.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">An institution may choose not to capture default and migration risks for debt instruments in its internal model where it is capturing those risks through the requirements set out in Section 4.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p307 ft1">49</P>
</DIV>
<DIV id="page_51">


<P class="p10 ft33"><SPAN class="ft32">S</SPAN>ECTION <SPAN class="ft32">4</SPAN></P>
<P class="p308 ft33"><SPAN class="ft32">I</SPAN>NTERNAL MODEL FOR INCREMENTAL DEFAULT AND MIGRATION RISK</P>
<P class="p141 ft8">Article 361</P>
<P class="p309 ft8">Requirement to have an internal IRC model</P>
<P class="p46 ft1">An institution that use an internal model for calculating own funds requirements for specific risk of debt instruments shall also have an internal incremental default and migration risk (IRC) model in place to capture the default and migration risks of its trading book positions that are incremental to the risks captured by the <NOBR>value-at-risk</NOBR> measure as specified in Article 354(1). An institution shall demonstrate that its internal model meets soundness standards comparable to the IRB approach for credit risk under the assumption of a constant level of risk, and adjusted where appropriate to reflect the impact of liquidity, concentrations, hedging and optionality.</P>
<P class="p310 ft8">Article 362</P>
<P class="p311 ft8">M48</P>
<P class="p312 ft8">Scope of the internal IRC model</P>
<P class="p47 ft1">The internal IRC model shall cover all positions subject to an own funds requirement for specific interest rate risk, including those subject to a 0% specific risk capital charge under Article 325, but shall not cover securitisation positions and <NOBR>n-th-to-default</NOBR> credit derivatives.</P>
<P class="p48 ft1">The institution may, subject to permission by the competent authorities<SPAN class="ft2">, </SPAN>choose to consistently include all listed equity positions and derivatives positions based on listed equities. The permission shall be granted <SPAN class="ft60">i</SPAN>f such inclusion is consistent with how the institution internally measures and manages risk.</P>
<P class="p95 ft8">Article 363</P>
<P class="p313 ft8">Parameters of the internal IRC model</P>
<P class="p33 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">1.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">Institutions shall use the internal model to calculate a number which measures losses due to default and internal or external ratings migration at the 99,9 % confidence interval over a time horizon of one year. Institutions shall calculate this number at least weekly.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p18 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">2.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">Correlation assumptions shall be supported by analysis of objective data in a conceptually sound framework. The internal model shall appropriately reflect issuer concentrations. Concentrations that can arise within and across product classes under stressed conditions shall also be reflected.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p114 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">3.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">The internal IRC model shall reflect the impact of correlations between default and migration events. The impact of diversification between, on the one hand, default and migration events and, on the other hand, other risk factors shall not be reflected.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p18 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">4.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">The internal model shall be based on the assumption of a constant level of risk over the one- year time horizon, implying that given individual trading book positions or sets of positions that have experienced default or migration over their liquidity horizon are </SPAN><NOBR>re-balanced</NOBR> at the end of their liquidity horizon to attain the initial level of risk. Alternatively, an institution may choose to consistently use a <NOBR>one-year</NOBR> constant position assumption.</P>
<P class="p251 ft1">50</P>
</DIV>
<DIV id="page_52">


<P class="p193 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">5.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">The liquidity horizons shall be set according to the time required to sell the position or to hedge all material relevant price risks in a stressed market, having particular regard to the size of the position. Liquidity horizons shall reflect actual practice and experience during periods of both systematic and idiosyncratic stresses. The liquidity horizon shall be measured under conservative assumptions and shall be sufficiently long that the act of selling or hedging, in itself, would not materially affect the price at which the selling or hedging would be executed.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p119 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">6.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">The determination of the appropriate liquidity horizon for a position or set of positions is subject to a floor of three months.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p18 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">7.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">The determination of the appropriate liquidity horizon for a position or set of positions shall take into account an institution's internal policies relating to valuation adjustments and the management of stale positions. When an institution determines liquidity horizons for sets of positions rather than for individual positions, the criteria for defining sets of positions shall be defined in a way that meaningfully reflects differences in liquidity. The liquidity horizons shall be greater for positions that are concentrated, reflecting the longer period needed to liquidate such positions. The liquidity horizon for a securitisation warehouse shall reflect the time to build, sell and securitise the assets, or to hedge the material risk factors, under stressed market conditions.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p314 ft8">Article 364</P>
<P class="p315 ft8">Recognition of hedges in the internal IRC model</P>
<P class="p33 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">1.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">Hedges may be incorporated into an institution's internal model to capture the incremental default and migration risks. Positions may be netted when long and short positions refer to the same financial instrument. Hedging or diversification effects associated with long and short positions involving different instruments or different securities of the same obligor, as well as long and short positions in different issuers, may only be recognised by explicitly modelling gross long and short positions in the different instruments. Institutions shall reflect the impact of material risks that could occur during the interval between the hedge's maturity and the liquidity horizon as well as the potential for significant basis risks in hedging strategies by product, seniority in the capital structure, internal or external rating, maturity, vintage and other differences in the instruments. An institution shall reflect a hedge only to the extent that it can be maintained even as the obligor approaches a credit or other event.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p316 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">2.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">For positions that are hedged via dynamic hedging strategies, a rebalancing of the hedge within the liquidity horizon of the hedged position may be recognised provided that the institution:</SPAN></P>
<P class="p34 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(a)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft12">chooses to model rebalancing of the hedge consistently over the relevant set of trading book positions;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p94 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(b)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft11">demonstrates that the inclusion of rebalancing results in a better risk measurement;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p21 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(c)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft12">demonstrates that the markets for the instruments serving as hedges are liquid enough to allow for such rebalancing even during periods of stress. Any residual risks resulting from dynamic hedging strategies must be reflected in the own funds requirement.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p317 ft1">51</P>
</DIV>
<DIV id="page_53">
<DIV id="dimg1">
<INGENBILD zsrc="GZB645253x1.jpg/" id="img1">
</DIV>


<P class="p26 ft8">Article 365</P>
<P class="p318 ft8">Particular requirements for the internal IRC model</P>
<P class="p33 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">1.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">The internal model to capture the incremental default and migration risks shall reflect the nonlinear impact of options, structured credit derivatives and other positions with material nonlinear behaviour with respect to price changes. The institution shall also have due regard to the amount of model risk inherent in the valuation and estimation of price risks associated with such products.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p20 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">2.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">The internal model shall be based on data that are objective and </SPAN><NOBR>up-to-date.</NOBR></P>
<P class="p29 ft4"><SPAN class="ft1">3.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft17">As part of the independent review and validation of their internal models used for purposes of this Chapter, an institution shall in particular do all of the following:</SPAN></P>
<P class="p22 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(a)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft12">validate that its modelling approach for correlations and price changes is appropriate for its portfolio, including the choice and weights of its systematic risk factors;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p21 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(b)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft11">perform a variety of stress tests, including sensitivity analysis and scenario analysis, to assess the qualitative and quantitative reasonableness of the internal model, particularly with regard to the treatment of concentrations. Such tests shall not be limited to the range of events experienced historically;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p35 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(c)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft12">apply appropriate quantitative validation including relevant internal modelling benchmarks.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p114 ft4"><SPAN class="ft1">4.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft17">The internal model shall be consistent with the institution's internal risk management methodologies for identifying, measuring, and managing trading risks.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p119 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">5.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">Institutions shall document their internal models so that its correlation and other modelling assumptions are transparent to the competent authorities.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p16 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">6.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">The internal model shall conservatively assess the risk arising from less liquid positions and positions with limited price transparency under realistic market scenarios. In addition, the internal model shall meet minimum data standards. Proxies shall be appropriately conservative and may be used only where available data is insufficient or is not reflective of the true volatility of a position or portfolio.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p105 ft8">Article 366</P>
<P class="p85 ft8">Not fully compliant IRC approaches</P>
<P class="p46 ft1">If an institution uses an internal model to capture incremental default and migration risks that does not comply with all requirements of Articles 363, 364 and 365 but that is consistent with the institution's internal methodologies for identifying, measuring and managing incremental default and migration risks, it shall be able to demonstrate that its internal model results in an own funds requirement that is at least as high as if it was based on a model in full compliance with the requirements of those Articles. The competent authorities shall review compliance with the previous sentence at least annually. EBA shall monitor the range of practices concerning internal models not complying with all requirements of Articles 363, 364 and 365 and shall, in accordance with Article 16 of Regulation (EU) No. 1093/2010, issue guidelines on those practices.</P>
<P class="p155 ft1">52</P>
</DIV>
<DIV id="page_54">


<P class="p10 ft33"><SPAN class="ft32">S</SPAN>ECTION <SPAN class="ft32">5</SPAN></P>
<P class="p319 ft33"><SPAN class="ft32">I</SPAN>NTERNAL MODEL FOR CORRELATION TRADING</P>
<P class="p141 ft8">Article 367</P>
<P class="p320 ft8">Requirements for an internal model for correlation trading</P>
<P class="p33 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">1.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">Competent authorities shall grant permission to use an internal model for the own funds requirement for the correlation trading portfolio instead of the own funds requirement according to Article 327 to institutions that are allowed to use an internal model for specific risk of debt instruments and that meet the requirements in paragraphs 2 to 6 and in Articles 356(1), 357, 358 and 359.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p149 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">2.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">Institutions shall use this internal model to calculate a number which adequately measures all price risks at the 99,9 % confidence interval over a time horizon of one year under the assumption of a constant level of risk, and adjusted where appropriate to reflect the impact of liquidity, concentrations, hedging and optionality. Institutions shall calculate this number at least weekly.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p20 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">3.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">The following risks shall be adequately captured by the model referred to in paragraph 1:</SPAN></P>
<P class="p21 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(a)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft12">the cumulative risk arising from multiple defaults, including different ordering of defaults, in tranched products;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p94 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(b)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft11">credit spread risk, including the gamma and </SPAN><NOBR>cross-gamma</NOBR> effects;</P>
<P class="p21 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(c)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft12">volatility of implied correlations, including the cross effect between spreads and correlations;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p244 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(d)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft11">basis risk, including both of the following:</SPAN></P>
<P class="p59 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(i)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft14">the basis between the spread of an index and those of its constituent single names;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p190 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(ii)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft15">the basis between the implied correlation of an index and that of bespoke portfolios;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p115 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(e)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft12">recovery rate volatility, as it relates to the propensity for recovery rates to affect tranche prices;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p115 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(f)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft30">to the extent the comprehensive risk measure incorporates benefits from dynamic hedging, the risk of hedge slippage and the potential costs of rebalancing such hedges;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p191 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(g)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft11">any other material price risks of positions in the correlation trading portfolio.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p33 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">4.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">An institution shall use sufficient market data within the model referred to in paragraph 1 in order to ensure that it fully captures the salient risks of those exposures in its internal approach in accordance with the requirements set out in this Article. It shall be able to demonstrate to the competent authority through back testing or other appropriate means that its model can appropriately explain the historical price variation of those products.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p321 ft1">53</P>
</DIV>
<DIV id="page_55">


<P class="p148 ft1">The institution shall have appropriate policies and procedures in place in order to separate the positions for which it holds permission to incorporate them in the own funds requirement in accordance with this Article from other positions for which it does not hold such permission.</P>
<P class="p18 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">5.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">With regard to the portfolio of all the positions incorporated in the model referred to in paragraph 1, the institution shall regularly apply a set of specific, predetermined stress scenarios. Such stress scenarios shall examine the effects of stress to default rates, recovery rates, credit spreads, basis risk, correlations and other relevant risk factors on the correlation trading portfolio. The institution shall apply stress scenarios at least weekly and report at least quarterly to the competent authorities the results, including comparisons with the institution's own funds requirement in accordance with this point. Any instances where the stress test results materially exceed the own funds requirement for the correlation trading portfolio shall be reported to the competent authorities in a timely manner.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p263 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">6.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">The internal model shall conservatively assess the risk arising from less liquid positions and positions with limited price transparency under realistic market scenarios. In addition, the internal model shall meet minimum data standards. Proxies shall be appropriately conservative and may be used only where available data is insufficient or is not reflective of the true volatility of a position or portfolio.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p322 ft1">54</P>
</DIV>
<DIV id="page_56">
<DIV id="dimg1">
<INGENBILD zsrc="GZB645256x1.jpg/" id="img1">
</DIV>


<P class="p168 ft6">Title V</P>
<P class="p323 ft6">Own Funds Requirements for Settlement Risk</P>
<P class="p324 ft8">Article 368</P>
<P class="p69 ft8">Settlement/delivery risk</P>
<P class="p325 ft1">In the case of transactions in which debt instruments, equities, foreign currencies and commodities excluding repurchase transactions and securities or commodities lending and securities or commodities borrowing are unsettled after their due delivery dates, an institution shall calculate the price difference to which it is exposed.</P>
<P class="p326 ft1">The price is calculated as difference between the agreed settlement price for the debt instrument, equity, foreign currency or commodity in question and its current market value, where the difference could involve a loss for the credit institution.</P>
<P class="p272 ft1">The institution shall multiply that price difference by the appropriate factor in column A of the following Table 1 in order to calculate the institution's own funds requirement for settlement risk.</P>

<P class="p329 ft8">Article 369</P>
<P class="p330 ft8">Free deliveries</P>
<P class="p70 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">1.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">An institution shall be required to hold own funds, as set out in Table 2, where the following occurs:</SPAN></P>
<P class="p331 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(a)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft12">it has paid for securities, foreign currencies or commodities before receiving them or it has delivered securities, foreign currencies or commodities before receiving payment for them;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p182 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(b)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft11">in the case of </SPAN><NOBR>cross-border</NOBR> transactions, one day or more has elapsed since it made that payment or delivery.</P>

<P class="p335 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">2.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">In applying a risk weight to free delivery exposures treated according to Column 3 of Table 2, an institution using the Internal Ratings Based approach set out in Part Three, Title II, Chapter 3 may assign PDs to counterparties, for which it has no other </SPAN><NOBR>non-trading</NOBR> book exposure, on the basis of the counterparty's external rating. Institutions using own estimates of LGDs may apply the LGD set out in Article 157(1) to free delivery exposures treated according to Column 3 of Table 2 provided that they apply it to all such exposures. Alternatively, an institution using the Internal Ratings Based approach set out in Part Three, Title II, Chapter 3 may apply the risk weights of the Standardised Approach, as set out in Part Three, Title II, Chapter 2 provided that it applies them to all such exposures or may apply a 100 % risk weight to all such exposures.</P>
<P class="p336 ft1">If the amount of positive exposure resulting from free delivery transactions is not material, institutions may apply a risk weight of 100 % to these exposures, except where a risk weight of 1 250% in accordance with Column 4 of Table 2 in paragraph 1 is required.</P>
<P class="p63 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">3.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">As an alternative to applying a risk weight of 1 250 % to free delivery exposures according to Column 4 of Table 2 in paragraph 1, institutions may deduct the value transferred plus the current positive exposure of those exposures from Common Equity Tier 1 items in accordance with point (k) of Article 33(1).</SPAN></P>
<P class="p337 ft8">Article 370</P>
<P class="p338 ft8">Waiver</P>
<P class="p325 ft1">Where a system wide failure of a settlement or clearing system occurs, competent authorities may waive the own funds requirements calculated as set out in Article 368 and 369 until the situation is rectified. In this case, the failure of a counterparty to settle a trade shall not be deemed a default for purposes of credit risk.</P>
<P class="p339 ft1">56</P>
</DIV>
<DIV id="page_58">


<P class="p132 ft6">Title VI</P>
<P class="p340 ft6">Own funds requirements for credit valuation adjustment risk</P>
<P class="p341 ft8">Article 371</P>
<P class="p342 ft8">Meaning of Credit Value Adjustment</P>
<P class="p47 ft1">For the purposes of this Title and Chapter 6 of Title III, Credit Valuation Adjustment or 'CVA' means an adjustment to the <NOBR>mid-market</NOBR> valuation of the portfolio of transactions with a counterparty. That adjustment reflects the current market value of the credit risk of the counterparty to the institution, but does not reflect the current market value of the credit risk of the institution to the counterparty.</P>
<P class="p95 ft8">Article 372</P>
<P class="p343 ft8">Scope</P>
<P class="p33 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">1.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">An institution shall calculate the own funds requirements for CVA risk in accordance with this Title for all OTC derivative instruments in respect of all of its business activities, other than credit derivatives recognised to reduce </SPAN><NOBR>risk-weighted</NOBR> exposure amounts for credit risk.</P>
<P class="p18 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">2.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">An institution shall include securities financing transactions in the calculation of own funds required by paragraph 1 if the competent authority determines that the institution's CVA risk exposures arising from those transactions are material.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p18 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">3.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">Transactions with a central counterparty are excluded from the own funds requirements for CVA risk.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p31 ft8">Article 373</P>
<P class="p344 ft8">Advanced method</P>
<P class="p33 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">1.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">An institution which has permission to use an internal model for the specific risk of debt instruments in accordance with Article 352 shall, for all transactions for which it has permission to use the IMM for determining the exposure value for the associated counterparty credit risk exposure in accordance with Article 277, determine the own funds requirements for CVA risk by modelling the impact of changes in the counterparties credit spreads on the CVAs of all counterparties of these transactions, taking into account CVA hedges that are eligible in accordance with Article 375.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p345 ft1">An institution shall use its internal model for determining the own funds requirements for specific risk associated with traded debt positions and shall apply a 99 percent confidence interval and a 10 day equivalent holding period. The internal model shall be used in such way that it simulates changes in the credit spreads of counterparties, but does not model the sensitivity of CVA to changes in other market factors, including changes in the value of the reference asset, commodity, currency or interest rate of a derivative.</P>
<P class="p19 ft1">The own funds requirements for CVA risk for each counterparty shall be calculated in accordance with the following formula:</P>
<P class="p346 ft1">57</P>
</DIV>

<P class="p352 ft22">LGD<SPAN class="ft54">MKT </SPAN>= the loss given default of the counterparty that shall be based on the spread of a market instrument of the counterparty if a counterparty instrument is available. Where a counterparty instrument is not available, it shall be based on the proxy spread that is appropriate having regard to the rating, industry and region of the counterparty. The first factor within the formula represents an approximation of the market implied marginal probability of a default occurring between times <NOBR>t<SPAN class="ft54">i-1</SPAN></NOBR></P>

<P class="p22 ft4"><SPAN class="ft1">(c)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft10">where the model uses </SPAN><NOBR>second-order</NOBR> sensitivities to shifts in credit spreads (spread gamma), the gammas shall be calculated based on the formula in paragraph 1.</P>
<P class="p281 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">3.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">An institution using the EPE measure for collateralised OTC derivatives referred to in point</SPAN></P>
<P class="p368 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(a)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft89">or (b) of Article 279(1) shall, when determining the own funds requirements for CVA risk in accordance with paragraph 1, do both of the following:</SPAN></P>
<P class="p191 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(a)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft12">assume a constant EE profile;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p39 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(b)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft11">set EE equal to the effective expected exposure as calculated under Article 279(1)(b) for a maturity equal to the greater of the following:</SPAN></P>
<P class="p369 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(i)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft90">half of the longest maturity occurring in the netting set;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p369 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(ii)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft91">the notional weighted average maturity of all transactions inside the netting set.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p16 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">4.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">An institution which is permitted by the competent authority in accordance with Article 277 to use IMM to calculate exposure values in relation to the majority of its business, but which uses the method set out in Section 3 or Section 4 of Title II, Chapter 6 for smaller portfolios, and which is permitted to use the market risk internal models approach for specific risk of traded debt instruments in accordance with Article 352 may, subject to permission from the competent authorities, calculate the own funds requirements for CVA risk in accordance with paragraph 1 for the </SPAN><NOBR>non-IMM</NOBR> netting sets. Competent authorities shall grant this permission only if the institution uses the method set out in Section 3 or Section 4 of Title II, Chapter 6 for a limited number of smaller portfolios.</P>
<P class="p370 ft1">For the purposes of a calculation under the preceding subparagraph and where the IMM model does not produce an expected exposure profile, an institution shall do both of the following:</P>
<P class="p94 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(a)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft12">assume a constant EE profile;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p21 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(b)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft11">set EE equal to the exposure value as computed under the methods set out in Section 3 or Section 5 of Title II, Chapter 6, or IMM for a maturity equal to the greater of:</SPAN></P>
<P class="p60 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(i)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft14">half of the longest maturity occurring in the netting set;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p60 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(ii)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft15">the notional weighted average maturity of all transactions inside the netting set.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p28 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">5.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">An institution shall determine the own funds requirements for CVA risk as the sum of non- stressed and stressed </SPAN><NOBR>Value-at-Risk,</NOBR> which shall be calculated as follows:</P>
<P class="p35 ft4"><SPAN class="ft1">(a)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft10">for the </SPAN><NOBR>non-stressed</NOBR> <NOBR>Value-at-Risk,</NOBR> current parameter calibrations for expected exposure shall be used;</P>
<P class="p22 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(b)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft11">for the stressed </SPAN><NOBR>Value-at-Risk,</NOBR> future counterparty EE profiles using a stressed calibration as set out in Article 286(2) shall be used. The period of stress for the credit</P>
<P class="p371 ft1">59</P>

<P class="p111 ft1">spread parameters shall be the most severe <NOBR>one-year</NOBR> stress period contained within the <NOBR>three-year</NOBR> stress period used for the exposure parameters.</P>
<P class="p107 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">6.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">EBA shall develop draft regulatory technical standards to specify in greater detail:</SPAN></P>
<P class="p21 ft4"><SPAN class="ft1">(a)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft10">how a proxy spread should be determined for the purposes of identifying LGD</SPAN><SPAN class="ft57">MKT </SPAN>for the purposes of the calculation required by paragraph 1;</P>
<P class="p22 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(b)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft11">the number and size of portfolios that fulfil the criterion of a limited number of smaller portfolios referred to in paragraph 4.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p24 ft1">EBA shall submit those draft regulatory technical standards to the Commission by 1 January 2013.</P>
<P class="p153 ft1">Power is delegated to the Commission to adopt the regulatory technical standards referred to in the first <NOBR>sub-paragraph</NOBR> in accordance with the procedure laid down in Articles 10 to 14 of Regulation (EU) No 1093/2010.</P>
<P class="p44 ft8">Article 374</P>
<P class="p372 ft8">Standardised method</P>
<P class="p16 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">1.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">An institution which does not calculate the own funds requirements for CVA risk for its counterparties in accordance with Article 373 shall calculate a portfolio own funds requirements for CVA risk for each counterparty in accordance with the following formula, taking into account CVA hedges that are eligible in accordance with Article 375:</SPAN></P>

<TR>
<TD rowspan=2 class="tr33 td254"><P class="p9 ft94">K <SPAN class="ft92">=</SPAN><SPAN class="ft93">2.33 </SPAN></P></TD>
<TD rowspan=2 class="tr33 td255"><P class="p9 ft96"><SPAN class="ft95">h </SPAN></P></TD>
<TD class="tr18 td193"><P class="p9 ft18"> </P></TD>
<TD rowspan=2 class="tr33 td27"><P class="p373 ft94">0.5</P></TD>
<TD class="tr18 td256"><P class="p9 ft18"> </P></TD>
<TD class="tr18 td257"><P class="p359 ft97">2</P></TD>
<TD class="tr18 td258"><P class="p355 ft98">2</P></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD class="tr15 td193"><P class="p9 ft18"> </P></TD>

<TD class="tr15 td258"><P class="p374 ft100"><SPAN class="ft92">+ </SPAN><SPAN class="ft94">0.75 w</SPAN><SPAN class="ft102">i</SPAN>2 <SPAN class="ft99">(</SPAN><SPAN class="ft94">M</SPAN><SPAN class="ft102">i </SPAN><SPAN class="ft94">EAD</SPAN><SPAN class="ft102">i</SPAN>total <NOBR><SPAN class="ft92">-</SPAN><SPAN class="ft94">M</SPAN><SPAN class="ft102">i</SPAN>hedge<SPAN class="ft94">B</SPAN><SPAN class="ft102">i</SPAN></NOBR><SPAN class="ft102"> </SPAN><SPAN class="ft99">)</SPAN></P></TD>

<TD class="tr35 td254"><P class="p9 ft18"> </P></TD>

<TD class="tr35 td27"><P class="p75 ft98">i</P></TD>
<TD class="tr35 td256"><P class="p375 ft49">ind</P></TD>
<TD class="tr35 td257"><P class="p9 ft18"> </P></TD>

<P class="p253 ft1">where:</P>
<P class="p205 ft1"><SPAN class="ft8">h </SPAN>= the <NOBR>one-year</NOBR> risk horizon (in units of a year); h = 1;</P>
<P class="p205 ft1"><SPAN class="ft8">w</SPAN><SPAN class="ft103">i </SPAN>= the weight applicable to counterparty "i".</P>
<P class="p377 ft1">Counterparty "i" shall be mapped to one of the seven weights w<SPAN class="ft54">i </SPAN>based on an external credit assessment by a nominated ECAI, as set out in Table 1. For a counterparty for which a credit assessment by a nominated ECAI is not available:</P>
<P class="p235 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(a)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft12">an institution using the approach in Title II, Chapter 3 shall map the internal rating of the counterparty to one of the external credit assessment;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p287 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(b)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft11">an institution using the approach in Title II, Chapter 2 shall assign credit quality step 3 to this counterparty;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p378 ft1"><SPAN class="ft8">EAD</SPAN><SPAN class="ft46">i</SPAN><SPAN class="ft104">total </SPAN>= the total counterparty credit risk exposure value of counterparty "i" (summed</P>
<P class="p379 ft1">across its netting sets) including the effect of collateral in accordance with the methods set out in Sections 3 to 6 of Title II, Chapter 6 as applicable to the</P>
<P class="p247 ft1">60</P>
</DIV>
<DIV id="page_62">


<P class="p380 ft1">calculation of the own funds requirements for counterparty credit risk for that counterparty.</P>
<P class="p381 ft1">For an institution not using the method set out in Section 6 of Title II, Chapter 6, the exposure shall be discounted by applying the following factor:</P>
<TABLE cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 class="t19">
<TR>
<TD rowspan=2 class="tr8 td131"><P class="p9 ft60">1 <NOBR><SPAN class="ft105">-</SPAN><SPAN class="ft106">e</SPAN></NOBR></P></TD>
<TD class="tr30 td260"><P class="p9 ft110"><NOBR><SPAN class="ft107">-</SPAN>0.05</NOBR> <SPAN class="ft108">M</SPAN><SPAN class="ft109">i</SPAN></P></TD>
<TD rowspan=3 class="tr36 td196"><P class="p355 ft1">;</P></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD class="tr26 td260"><P class="p9 ft37"> </P></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD colspan=2 class="tr19 td181"><P class="p75 ft1">0.05 <SPAN class="ft8">M</SPAN><SPAN class="ft46">i</SPAN></P></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P class="p382 ft4"><SPAN class="ft111">B</SPAN><SPAN class="ft112">i </SPAN>= the notional of purchased single name credit default swap hedges (summed if more than one position) referencing counterparty "i" and used to hedge CVA risk.</P>
<P class="p383 ft1">That notional amount shall be discounted by applying the following factor:</P>
<TABLE cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 class="t20">
<TR>
<TD rowspan=2 class="tr8 td261"><P class="p9 ft1"><NOBR>1<SPAN class="ft40">-</SPAN><SPAN class="ft8">e</SPAN></NOBR></P></TD>
<TD class="tr24 td178"><P class="p9 ft61"><NOBR><SPAN class="ft53">-</SPAN>0.05</NOBR> <SPAN class="ft45">M</SPAN><SPAN class="ft113">i</SPAN><SPAN class="ft114">hedge</SPAN></P></TD>
<TD rowspan=3 class="tr37 td196"><P class="p355 ft1">;</P></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD class="tr7 td170"><P class="p9 ft20"> </P></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD colspan=2 class="tr19 td262"><P class="p354 ft1">0.05 <SPAN class="ft8">M</SPAN><SPAN class="ft46">i</SPAN><SPAN class="ft104">hedge</SPAN></P></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P class="p384 ft1"><SPAN class="ft8">B</SPAN><SPAN class="ft103">ind </SPAN>= is the full notional of one or more index credit default swap of purchased protection used to hedge CVA risk.</P>
<P class="p385 ft1">That notional amount shall be discounted by applying the following factor:</P>
<P class="p386 ft121"><NOBR><SPAN class="ft115">1</SPAN><SPAN class="ft116">-</SPAN><SPAN class="ft117">e</SPAN><SPAN class="ft118">-</SPAN>0.05</NOBR> <SPAN class="ft119">M</SPAN><SPAN class="ft120">ind</SPAN></P>
<P class="p387 ft122">;</P>
<P class="p388 ft1">0.05 <SPAN class="ft8">M</SPAN><SPAN class="ft46">ind</SPAN></P>
<P class="p389 ft1">w<SPAN class="ft54">ind </SPAN>=is the weight applicable to index hedges.</P>
<P class="p390 ft1">An institution shall map indices to one of the seven weights w<SPAN class="ft54">i </SPAN>based on the average spread of index ind;</P>
<P class="p205 ft1">M<SPAN class="ft54">i </SPAN>= the effective maturity of the transactions with counterparty i.</P>
<P class="p391 ft1">For an institution using the method set out in Section 6 of Title II, Chapter 6, M<SPAN class="ft54">i </SPAN>shall be calculated in accordance with Article 158(2)(f).</P>
<P class="p392 ft1">For an institution not using the method set out in Section 6 of Title II, Chapter 6, M<SPAN class="ft54">i </SPAN>is the average notional weighted maturity as referred to in point Article 158(2);</P>
<P class="p393 ft127"><SPAN class="ft123">M</SPAN><SPAN class="ft124">i</SPAN><SPAN class="ft125">hedge </SPAN>= the maturity of the hedge instrument with notional B<SPAN class="ft126">i </SPAN>(the quantities Mihedge Bi are to be summed if these are several positions);</P>
<P class="p394 ft1">M<SPAN class="ft54">ind </SPAN>= the maturity of the index hedge ind.</P>
<P class="p395 ft1">In case of more than one index hedge position, M<SPAN class="ft54">ind </SPAN>is the <NOBR>notional-weighted</NOBR> maturity.</P>
<P class="p16 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">2.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">Where a counterparty is included in an index on which a credit default swap used for hedging counterparty credit risk is based, the institution may subtract the notional amount attributable to that counterparty in accordance with its reference entity weight from the index CDS</SPAN></P>
<P class="p396 ft1">61</P>
</DIV>

</DIV>


<P class="p231 ft1">notional amount and treated as a single name hedge (B<SPAN class="ft54">i</SPAN>) of the individual counterparty with maturity based on the maturity of the index.</P>

<P class="p400 ft8">Article 375</P>
<P class="p401 ft8">Eligible hedges</P>
<P class="p33 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">1.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">Hedges shall be 'eligible hedges' for the purposes of the calculation of own funds requirements for CVA risk in accordance with Article 373 and Article 374 only where they are used for the purpose of mitigating CVA risk and managed as such, and are one of the following:</SPAN></P>
<P class="p40 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(a)</SPAN><NOBR><SPAN class="ft12">single-name</SPAN></NOBR> credit default swaps or other equivalent hedging instruments referencing the counterparty directly;</P>
<P class="p21 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(b)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft11">index credit default swaps, provided that the basis between any individual counterparty spread and the spreads of index credit default swap hedges is reflected in the </SPAN><NOBR>Value-at-</NOBR> Risk.</P>
<P class="p152 ft1">The requirement in point (b) that the basis between any individual counterparty spread and the spreads of index credit default swap hedges is reflected in the <NOBR>Value-at-Risk</NOBR> shall also apply to cases where a proxy is used for the spread of a counterparty.</P>
<P class="p402 ft4">For all counterparties for which a proxy is used, an institution shall use reasonable basis time series out of a representative group of similar names for which a spread is available.</P>
<P class="p19 ft1">If the basis between any individual counterparty spread and the spreads of index credit default swap hedges is not reflected to the satisfaction of the competent authority, then an institution shall reflect only 50% of the notional amount of index hedges in the <NOBR>Value-at-Risk.</NOBR></P>
<P class="p17 ft4">The hedges referred to in point (b) may be used only for the purposes of the calculation of own funds requirements for CVA risk in accordance with Article 373.</P>
<P class="p403 ft1">62</P>
</DIV>
<DIV id="page_64">


<P class="p193 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">2.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">An institution shall not reflect other types of counterparty risk hedges in the calculation of the own funds requirements for CVA risk. In particular, tranched or </SPAN><NOBR>nth-to-default</NOBR> credit default swaps and credit linked notes are not eligible hedges for the purposes the calculation of the own funds requirements for CVA risk.</P>
<P class="p18 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">3.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">Eligible hedges that are included in the calculation of the own funds requirements for CVA risk shall not be included in the calculation of the own funds requirements for specific risk as set out in Title IV or treated as credit risk mitigation other than for the counterparty credit risk of the same portfolio of transaction.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p404 ft1">63</P>
</DIV>
<DIV id="page_65">


<P class="p150 ft6">PART FOUR</P>
<P class="p405 ft6">LARGE EXPOSURES</P>
<P class="p406 ft33"><SPAN class="ft32">S</SPAN>ECTION <SPAN class="ft32">I</SPAN></P>
<P class="p259 ft33"><SPAN class="ft32">L</SPAN>ARGE EXPOSURE REGIME</P>
<P class="p105 ft8">Article 376</P>
<P class="p137 ft8">Subject matter</P>
<P class="p100 ft1">Institutions shall monitor and control their large exposures in accordance with this Part.</P>
<P class="p407 ft8">Article 377</P>
<P class="p401 ft8">Negative Scope</P>
<P class="p408 ft1">This Part shall not apply to investment firms that fulfil the criteria set out in Article 90(1) or Article 91(1).</P>
<P class="p14 ft8">Article 378</P>
<P class="p409 ft8">Definition</P>
<P class="p100 ft1">The following definition applies for the purposes of this Part:</P>
<P class="p219 ft1">Exposures, for the purposes of this Part means any asset or <NOBR>off-balance-sheet</NOBR> item referred to in Part Three, Title II, Chapter 2, without risk weights or degrees of risk.</P>
<P class="p31 ft8">Article 379</P>
<P class="p146 ft8">Calculation of the exposure value</P>
<P class="p33 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">1.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">Exposures arising from the items referred to in Annex II shall be calculated in accordance with one of the methods set out in Part Three, Title II, Chapter 6.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p16 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">2.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">Institutions with a permission to use the Internal Model Method in accordance with Article 277 may use the Internal Model Method for calculating the exposure value for repurchase transactions, securities or commodities lending or borrowing transactions, margin lending transactions and long settlement transactions.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p119 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">3.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">The exposures to individual clients which arise on the trading book shall be calculated by those institutions that calculate the own funds requirements for their </SPAN><NOBR>trading-book</NOBR> business in accordance with Part Three, Title IV, Chapter 2, Article 293 and Part Three, Title V and, as appropriate, with Part Three, Title IV, Chapter 5, by summing the following items:</P>
<P class="p35 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(a)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft12">the positive excess of an institution's long positions over its short positions in all the financial instruments issued by the client in question, the net position in each of the different instruments being calculated according to the methods laid down in Part Three, Title IV, Chapter 2;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p410 ft1">64</P>
</DIV>
<DIV id="page_66">


<P class="p411 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(b)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft11">the net exposure, in the case of the underwriting of a debt or an equity instrument;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p39 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(c)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft12">the exposures due to the transactions, agreements and contracts referred to in Articles 293 and 368 to 370 with the client in question, such exposures being calculated in the manner laid down in those Articles, for the calculation of exposure values.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p402 ft1">For the purposes of point (b), the net exposure is calculated by deducting those underwriting positions which are subscribed or <NOBR>sub-underwritten</NOBR> by third parties on the basis of a formal agreement reduced by the factors set out in Article 334.</P>
<P class="p17 ft1">For the purposes of point (b), institutions shall set up systems to monitor and control their underwriting exposures between the time of the initial commitment and the next business day in the light of the nature of the risks incurred in the markets in question.</P>
<P class="p17 ft1">For the purposes of point (c), Part Three, Title II, Chapter 3 shall be excluded from the reference in Article 293.</P>
<P class="p16 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">4.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">The overall exposures to individual clients or groups of connected clients shall be calculated by summing the exposures of the trading book and those of the </SPAN><NOBR>non-trading</NOBR> book.</P>
<P class="p16 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">5.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">The exposures to groups of connected clients shall be calculated by summing the exposures to individual clients in a group.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p107 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">6.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">Exposures shall not include any of the following:</SPAN></P>
<P class="p97 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(a)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft12">in the case of foreign exchange transactions, exposures incurred in the ordinary course of settlement during the two working days following payment;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p21 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(b)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft11">in the case of transactions for the purchase or sale of securities, exposures incurred in the ordinary course of settlement during five working days following payment or delivery of the securities, whichever the earlier;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p35 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(c)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft12">in the case of the provision of money transmission including the execution of payment services, clearing and settlement in any currency and correspondent banking or financial instruments clearing, settlement and custody services to clients, delayed receipts in funding and other exposures arising from client activity which do not last longer than the following business day;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p109 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(d)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft11">in the case of the provision of money transmission including the execution of payment services, clearing and settlement in any currency and correspondent banking, </SPAN><NOBR>intra-day</NOBR> exposures to institutions providing those services;</P>
<P class="p191 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(e)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft12">exposures deducted from own funds in accordance with Articles 33, 53 and 63.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p16 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">7.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">In order to determine the existence of a group of connected clients, in respect of exposures referred to in points (l) and (n) of 107 where there is an exposure to underlying assets, and in respect of exposures referred to in point (p) of Article 107 where there is a scheme and an exposure to underlying assets, an institution shall assess the scheme, its underlying exposures, or both. For that purpose, an institution shall evaluate the economic substance and the risks inherent in the structure of the transaction.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p412 ft1">65</P>
</DIV>
<DIV id="page_67">


<P class="p413 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">8.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">EBA shall develop draft regulatory technical standards to specify the following:</SPAN></P>
<P class="p39 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(a)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft12">which exposures referred to in point (p) of Article 107 are subject to the treatment of this paragraph;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p40 ft4"><SPAN class="ft1">(b)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft13">the conditions and methodologies used to determine the existence of a group of connected clients in respect of such exposures.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p19 ft1">EBA shall submit those draft regulatory technical standards to the Commission by 1 January 2014.</P>
<P class="p153 ft1">Power is delegated to the Commission to adopt the regulatory technical standards referred to in the first subparagraph in accordance with the procedure laid down in Articles 10 to 14 of Regulation (EU) No. 1093/2010.</P>
<P class="p95 ft8">Article 380</P>
<P class="p319 ft8">Definition of an institution for large exposures purposes</P>
<P class="p46 ft1">For the purposes of calculating the value of exposures in accordance with this Part the term 'institution' also means any private or public undertaking, including its branches, which meets the definition of institution and has been authorised in a third country.</P>
<P class="p95 ft8">Article 381</P>
<P class="p414 ft8">Definition of a large exposure</P>
<P class="p46 ft1">An institution's exposure to a client or group of connected clients shall be considered a large exposure where its value is equal to or exceeds 10 % of its eligible capital.</P>
<P class="p31 ft8">Article 382</P>
<P class="p415 ft8">Capacity to identify and manage large exposures</P>
<P class="p416 ft1">An institution shall have sound administrative and accounting procedures and adequate internal control mechanisms for the purposes of identifying, managing, monitoring, reporting and recording all large exposures and subsequent changes to them, in accordance with this Regulation</P>
<P class="p95 ft8">Article 383</P>
<P class="p171 ft8">Reporting requirements</P>
<P class="p107 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">1.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">An institution shall report the following information about every large exposure to the</SPAN></P>
<P class="p231 ft1">competent authorities, including large exposures exempted from the application of Article 384(1)</P>
<P class="p417 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(a)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft12">the identification of the client or the group of connected clients to which an institution has a large exposure;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p35 ft4"><SPAN class="ft1">(b)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft13">the exposure value before taking into account the effect of the credit risk mitigation, when applicable;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p418 ft1">66</P>
</DIV>
<DIV id="page_68">


<P class="p411 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(c)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft12">where used, the type of funded or unfunded credit protection;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p39 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(d)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft11">the exposure value after taking into account the effect of the credit risk mitigation calculated for the purpose of Article 384(1).</SPAN></P>
<P class="p17 ft1">Where an institution is subject to Part Three, Title II, Chapter 3 its 20 largest exposures on a consolidated basis, excluding those exempted from the application of Article 384(1) shall be made available to the competent authorities.</P>
<P class="p107 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">2.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">Reporting shall be carried out at least twice a year.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p107 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">3.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">EBA shall develop draft implementing technical standards to specify the following:</SPAN></P>
<P class="p21 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(a)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft12">the uniform formats for the reporting referred to in paragraph 2 which shall be proportionate to the nature, scale and complexity of institutions' activities and the instructions for using those formats;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p94 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(b)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft11">the frequencies and dates of the reporting referred to in paragraph 2;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p94 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(c)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft12">the IT solutions to be applied for the reporting referred to in paragraph 2.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p24 ft1">EBA shall submit those draft implementing technical standards to the Commission by 1 January 2013.</P>
<P class="p153 ft1">Power is conferred to the Commission to adopt the implementing technical standards referred to in the first subparagraph in accordance with the procedure laid down in Article 15 of Regulation (EU) No 1093/2010.</P>
<P class="p31 ft8">Article 384</P>
<P class="p150 ft8">Large exposures limit</P>
<P class="p16 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">1.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">An institution shall not incur an exposure, after taking into account the effect of the credit risk mitigation in accordance with Articles 388 to 392, to a client or group of connected clients the value of which exceeds 25 % of its eligible capital Where that client is an institution or where a group of connected clients includes one or more institutions, that value shall not exceed 25 % of the institution's eligible capital or EUR 150 million, whichever the higher, provided that the sum of exposure values, after taking into account the effect of the credit risk mitigation in accordance with Articles 388 to 392, to all connected clients that are not institutions does not exceed 25 % of the institutions eligible capital</SPAN></P>
<P class="p419 ft1">Where the amount of EUR 150 million is higher than 25 % of the institutions eligible capital the value of the exposure, after taking into account the effect of credit risk mitigation in accordance with Articles 388 to 392 shall not exceed a reasonable limit in terms of the institutions eligible capital That limit shall be determined by the institution in accordance with the policies and procedures referred to in Article 79 of Directive [inserted by OP], to address and control concentration risk. This limit shall not exceed 100 % of the institutions eligible capital</P>
<P class="p420 ft1">Competent authorities may set a lower limit than EUR 150 million and shall inform EBA and the Commission thereof.</P>
<P class="p421 ft1">67</P>
</DIV>
<DIV id="page_69">


<P class="p193 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">2.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">Subject to Article 385, an institution shall at all times comply with the relevant limit laid down in paragraph 1.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p29 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">3.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">Assets constituting claims and other exposures onto recognised third country investment firms may be subject to the same treatment as laid down in paragraph 1.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p16 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">4.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">The limits laid down in this Article may be exceeded for the exposures on the institution's trading book if the following conditions are met:</SPAN></P>
<P class="p21 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(a)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft12">the exposure on the </SPAN><NOBR>non-trading</NOBR> book to the client or group of clients in question does not exceed the limit laid down in paragraph 1, this limit being calculated with reference to eligible capital, so that the excess arises entirely on the trading book;</P>
<P class="p35 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(b)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft11">the institution meets an additional own funds requirement on the excess in respect of the limit laid down in paragraph 1 which is calculated in accordance with Articles 386 and 387;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p34 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(c)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft12">where 10 days or less have elapsed since the excess occurred, the </SPAN><NOBR>trading-book</NOBR> exposure to the client or group of connected clients in question shall not exceed 500 % of the institution's eligible capital;</P>
<P class="p35 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(d)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft11">any excesses that have persisted for more than 10 days do not, in aggregate, exceed 600 % of the institution's eligible capital.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p422 ft1">In each case in which the limit has been exceeded, the institution shall report the amount of the excess and the name of the client concerned without delay to the competent authorities.</P>
<P class="p31 ft8">Article 385</P>
<P class="p423 ft8">Compliance with Large exposures requirements</P>
<P class="p33 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">1.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">If, in an exceptional case, exposures exceed the limit set out in Article 384(1), the institution shall report the value of the exposure without delay to the competent authorities which may, where the circumstances warrant it, allow the credit institution a limited period of time in which to comply with the limit.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p19 ft1">Where the amount of EUR 150 million referred to in Article 384(1) is applicable, the competent authorities may allow on a <NOBR>case-by-case</NOBR> basis the 100 % limit in terms of the credit institution's own funds to be exceeded.</P>
<P class="p18 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">2.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">Where compliance by a institution on an individual or </SPAN><NOBR>sub-consolidated</NOBR> basis with the obligations imposed in this Part is disapplied under Article 6(1), or the provisions of Article 8 are applied in the case of parent institutions in a Member State, measures must be taken to ensure the satisfactory allocation of risks within the group.</P>
<P class="p95 ft8">Article 386</P>
<P class="p424 ft8">Calculating additional own funds requirements for large exposures in the trading book</P>
<P class="p28 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">1.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">The excess referred to in Article 384(4)(b) shall be calculated by selecting those components of the total trading exposure to the client or group of clients in question which attract the</SPAN></P>
<P class="p425 ft1">68</P>
</DIV>
<DIV id="page_70">
<DIV id="dimg1">
<INGENBILD zsrc="GZB645270x1.jpg/" id="img1">
</DIV>


<P class="p148 ft1">highest <NOBR>specific-risk</NOBR> requirements in Part Three, Title IV, Chapter 2 and/or requirements in Article 293 and Part Three, Title V, the sum of which equals the amount of the excess referred to in point (a) of Article 384(4).</P>
<P class="p18 ft4"><SPAN class="ft1">2.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft17">Where the excess has not persisted for more than 10 days, the additional capital requirement shall be 200 % of the requirements referred to in paragraph 1, on these components.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p119 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">3.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">As from 10 days after the excess has occurred, the components of the excess, selected in accordance with paragraph 1, shall be allocated to the appropriate line in Column 1 of Table 1 in ascending order of </SPAN><NOBR>specific-risk</NOBR> requirements in Part Three, Title IV, Chapter 2 and/or requirements in Article 293 and Part Three, Title V. The additional own funds requirement shall be equal to the sum of the <NOBR>specific-risk</NOBR> requirements in Part Three, Title IV, Chapter 2 and/or the Article 293 and Part Three, Title V requirements on these components, multiplied by the corresponding factor in Column 2 of Table 1.</P>

<P class="p427 ft8">Article 387</P>
<P class="p428 ft8">Procedures to prevent avoiding the additional own funds requirement</P>
<P class="p47 ft1">Institutions shall not deliberately avoid the additional own funds requirements set out in Article 386 that they would otherwise incur, on exposures exceeding the limit laid down in Article 384(1) once those exposures have been maintained for more than 10 days, by means of temporarily transferring the exposures in question to another company, whether within the same group or not, and/or by undertaking artificial transactions to close out the exposure during the <NOBR>10-day</NOBR> period and create a new exposure.</P>
<P class="p429 ft1">Institutions shall maintain systems which ensure that any transfer which has the effect referred to in the first subparagraph is immediately reported to the competent authorities.</P>
<P class="p430 ft1">69</P>
</DIV>
<DIV id="page_71">


<P class="p26 ft8">Article 388</P>
<P class="p306 ft8">Eligible credit mitigation techniques</P>
<P class="p33 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">1.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">For the purposes of Articles 389 to 392 the term guarantee shall include credit derivatives recognised under Part Three, Title II, Chapter 4 other than credit linked notes.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p16 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">2.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">Subject to paragraph 3 of this Article, where, under Articles 389 to 392 the recognition of funded or unfunded credit protection is permitted, this shall be subject to compliance with the eligibility requirements and other requirements set out in Part Three, Title II, Chapter 4.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p18 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">3.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">Where a institution relies upon Article 390(2), the recognition of funded credit protection shall be subject to the relevant requirements under Part Three, Title II, Chapter 3 For the purposes of this Section, a credit institution shall not take into account the collateral referred to in Article 195, paragraphs 3 to 5, unless permitted under Article 391.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p18 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">4.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">Institutions shall analyse, to the extent possible, their exposures to collateral issuers, providers of unfunded credit protection and underlying assets pursuant to Article 379(7) for possible concentrations and where appropriate take action and report any significant findings to their competent authority.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p220 ft8">Article 389</P>
<P class="p431 ft8">Exemptions</P>
<P class="p432 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">1.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">The following exposures shall be exempted from the application of Article 384(1):</SPAN></P>
<P class="p21 ft4"><SPAN class="ft1">(a)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft10">asset items constituting claims on central governments or central banks which, unsecured, would be assigned a 0 % risk weight under Part Three, Title II, Chapter 2;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p433 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(b)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft11">asset items constituting claims on international organisations or multilateral development banks which, unsecured, would be assigned a 0 % risk weight under Part Three, Title II, Chapter 2;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p34 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(c)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft12">asset items constituting claims carrying the explicit guarantees of central governments, central banks, international organisations, multilateral development banks or public sector entities, where unsecured claims on the entity providing the guarantee would be assigned a 0 % risk weight under Part Three, Title II, Chapter 2;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p35 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(d)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft11">other exposures attributable to, or guaranteed by, central governments, central banks, international organisations, multilateral development banks or public sector entities, where unsecured claims on the entity to which the exposure is attributable or by which it is guaranteed would be assigned a 0 % risk weight under Part Three, Title II, Chapter 2;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p22 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(e)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft12">asset items constituting claims on regional governments or local authorities of Member States where those claims would be assigned a 0 % risk weight under Part Three, Title II, Chapter 2 and other exposures to or guaranteed by those regional governments or local authorities, claims on which would be assigned a 0 % risk weight under Part Three, Title II, Chapter 2;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p109 ft4"><SPAN class="ft1">(f)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft129">exposures to counterparties referred to in Article 108(6) or Article 108(7) if they would be assigned a 0 % risk weight under Part Three, Title II, Chapter 2. Exposures that do</SPAN></P>
<P class="p147 ft1">70</P>
</DIV>
<DIV id="page_72">


<P class="p111 ft1">not meet those criteria, whether or not exempted from Article 384(1) shall be treated as exposures to a third party;</P>
