<P class="p16 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">1.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">The provisions on capital requirements as set out in this Regulation shall not apply to investment firms whose main business consists exclusively of the provision of investment services or activities in relation to the financial instruments set out in points 5, 6, 7, 9 and 10 of Section C of Annex I to Directive 2004/39/EC and to whom Directive 93/22/EEC did not apply on 31 December 2006.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p451 ft4">This exemption shall apply until 31 December 2014 or the date of entry into force of any modifications pursuant to paragraphs 2 and 3, whichever is the earlier.</P>
<P class="p119 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">2.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">By 31 December 2014, the Commission shall, on the basis of public consultations and in the light of discussions with the competent authorities, report to the Parliament and the Council on:</SPAN></P>
<P class="p34 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(a)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft12">an appropriate regime for the prudential supervision of investment firms whose main business consists exclusively of the provision of investment services or activities in relation to the commodity derivatives or derivatives contracts set out in points 5, 6, 7, 9 and 10 of Section C of Annex I to Directive 2004/39/EC;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p35 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(b)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft11">the desirability of amending Directive 2004/39/EC to create a further category of investment firm whose main business consists exclusively of the provision of investment services or activities in relation to the financial instruments set out in points 5, 6, 7, 9 and 10 of Section C of Annex I to Directive 2004/39/EC relating to energy supplies, including electricity, coal, gas and oil.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p486 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">3.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">On the basis of the report referred to in paragraph 2, the Commission may submit proposals for amendments to this regulation.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p624 ft1">145</P>
</DIV>
<DIV id="page_147">


<P class="p26 ft8">Article 475</P>
<P class="p537 ft8">Leverage</P>
<P class="p33 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">1.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">By way of derogation from Article 416 and 417, during the period between 1 January 2013 and 31 December 2021, institutions shall calculate and report the leverage ratio by using both of the following as the capital measure:</SPAN></P>
<P class="p191 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(a)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft12">Tier 1 capital ;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p202 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(b)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft11">Tier 1 capital, subject to the derogations laid down in Chapters 2 and 3 of this Title.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p16 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">2.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">By way of derogation from Article 436(1), institutions may choose whether to disclose the information on the leverage ratio based on either just one or both of the definitions of the capital measure specified in points (a) and (b) of paragraph 1. Where institutions change their decision on which leverage ratio to disclose, the first disclosure that occurs after such change shall contain a reconciliation of the information on all leverage ratios disclosed up to the moment of the change.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p145 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">3.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">By way of derogation from Article 416(2), during the period from 1 January 2013 to 31 December 2017, competent authorities may permit institutions to calculate the </SPAN><NOBR>end-of-quarter</NOBR> leverage ratio where they consider that institutions may not have data of sufficiently good quality to calculate a leverage ratio that is an arithmetic mean of the monthly leverage ratios over a quarter.</P>
<P class="p44 ft8">Article 476</P>
<P class="p313 ft8">Transitional provisions – Basel I floor</P>
<P class="p16 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">1.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">Until 31 December 2015, institutions calculating </SPAN><NOBR>risk-weighted</NOBR> exposure amounts in accordance with Part Three, Title II, Chapter 3 and institutions using the Advanced Measurement Approaches as specified in Part Three, Title III, Chapter 4 for the calculation of their own funds requirements for operational risk shall meet both of the following requirements:</P>
<P class="p535 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(a)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft12">They shall hold own funds as required by Part Three Title II Chapter 1;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p21 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(b)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft130">They shall meet a temporary capital ratio of not less 6.4%. The temporary capital ratio is the own funds of the institution expressed as a percentage of the </SPAN><NOBR>risk-adjusted</NOBR> assets and <NOBR>off-balance</NOBR> sheet items as set out in Annex IV.</P>
<P class="p16 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">2.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">The competent authorities may, after having consulted EBA, waive the application of paragraph 1(b) to institutions provided that all the requirements for the Internal Ratings Based Approach set out in Part Three, Title II, Chapter 3, Section 6 and the qualifying criteria for the use of the Advanced Measurement Approach set out in Part Three, Title III, Chapter 4 are met.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p625 ft1">146</P>
</DIV>
<DIV id="page_148">


<P class="p26 ft6">Title II</P>
<P class="p626 ft6">Reports and reviews</P>
<P class="p341 ft8">Article 477</P>
<P class="p96 ft8">Cyclicality of capital requirements</P>
<P class="p47 ft1">The Commission, in cooperation with EBA, ESRB and the Member States, and taking into account the contribution of the European Central Bank, shall periodically monitor whether this Regulation taken as a whole, together with Directive [inserted by OP] has significant effects on the economic cycle and, in the light of that examination, shall consider whether any remedial measures are justified. By 31 December 2013, the EBA shall report to the Commission if and how methodologies of institutions under the IRB Approach should converge with a view to more comparable capital requirements while mitigating <NOBR>pro-cyclicality.</NOBR></P>
<P class="p455 ft1">Based on that analysis and taking into account the contribution of the European Central Bank, the Commission shall draw up a biennial report and submit it to the European Parliament and to the Council, together with any appropriate proposals. Contributions from credit taking and credit lending parties shall be adequately acknowledged when the report is drawn up.</P>
<P class="p95 ft8">Article 478</P>
<P class="p627 ft8">Own funds requirements for exposures in the form of covered bonds</P>
<P class="p47 ft1">The Commission shall, by 31 December 2015 and after consulting the EBA, report to the Parliament and the Council, together with any appropriate proposals, whether the risk weights laid down in Article 124 and the own funds requirements for specific risk in Article 325(5) are adequate for all the instruments that qualify for these treatments and whether the criteria in Article 124 should be made stricter.</P>
<P class="p44 ft8">Article 479</P>
<P class="p530 ft8">Large exposures</P>
<P class="p47 ft1">By 31 December 2013 the Commission shall review and report on the application of Article 389(1)(j) and 389(2), including whether exemptions in Article 389(2) should be discretionary, and shall submit this report to the European Parliament and the Council and, if appropriate, a legislative proposal.</P>
<P class="p48 ft1">With respect to the potential elimination of the national discretion under Article 389(2)(c) and its potential application at the Union level, the review shall in particular take into account the efficiency of groups risk management while ensuring that sufficient safeguards are in place to ensure financial stability in all Member states in which an entity of a group is incorporated.</P>
<P class="p628 ft1">147</P>
</DIV>
<DIV id="page_149">


<P class="p26 ft8">Article 480</P>
<P class="p226 ft8">Level of application</P>
<P class="p33 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">1.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">By 31 December 2013, the Commission shall review and report on the application of Part One, Title II, and Article 108(6) and 108(7) and shall submit this report to the European Parliament and the Council, and, if appropriate, a legislative proposal.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p18 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">2.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">By 31 December 2014, the Commission shall report on whether and how the liquidity coverage requirement laid down in Article 401 should apply to investment firms and shall, after consulting EBA, submit this report to the European Parliament and the Council, and, if appropriate, a legislative proposal.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p95 ft8">Article 481</P>
<P class="p262 ft8">Liquidity requirements</P>
<P class="p33 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">1.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">EBA shall monitor and evaluate the reports made in accordance with Article 403(1), across currencies and across different business models. EBA shall, and after consulting the ESRB, annually and for the first time by 31 December 2013 report to the Commission whether a specification of the general liquidity coverage requirement in Article 401 based on the criteria for liquidity reporting in Part Six Title II, considered either individually or cumulatively, is likely to have a material detrimental impact on the business and risk profile of Union institutions or on financial markets or the economy and bank lending, with a particular focus on lending to small and medium enterprises and on trade financing, including lending under official export credit insurance schemes.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p629 ft1">EBA shall in its report review in particular the appropriateness of the calibration of the following:</P>
<P class="p244 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(a)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft12">the mechanisms restricting the value of liquidity inflows;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p94 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(b)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft11">the outflows in accordance with Article 410(5);</SPAN></P>
<P class="p39 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(c)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft12">the appropriate haircuts for purposes of Article 406 for assets held in accordance with the derogations laid down to in Article 407.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p18 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">2.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">EBA shall, by 31 December 2013, report to the Commission on appropriate uniform definitions of high and of extremely high liquidity and credit quality of transferable assets for purposes of Article 404. EBA shall in particular test the adequacy of the following criteria and the appropriate levels for such definitions:</SPAN></P>
<P class="p191 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(a)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft12">minimum trade volume of the assets</SPAN></P>
<P class="p94 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(b)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft11">minimum outstanding volume of the assets</SPAN></P>
<P class="p202 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(c)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft12">transparent pricing and </SPAN><NOBR>post-trade</NOBR> information</P>
<P class="p94 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(d)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft11">credit quality steps referred to in </SPAN><NOBR>Sub-section</NOBR> 2 of Annex VI</P>
<P class="p202 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(e)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft12">proven record of price stability</SPAN></P>
<P class="p630 ft1">148</P>
</DIV>
<DIV id="page_150">


<P class="p411 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(f)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft30">average volume traded and average trade size</SPAN></P>
<P class="p202 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(g)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft11">maximum bid/ask spread</SPAN></P>
<P class="p94 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(h)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft11">remaining time to maturity</SPAN></P>
<P class="p94 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(i)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft30">minimum turnover ratio</SPAN></P>
<P class="p33 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">3.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">By 31 December 2015, EBA shall report to the Commission on whether and how it would be appropriate to ensure that institutions use stable sources of funding, including an assessment of the impact on the business and risk profile of Union institutions or on financial markets or the economy and bank lending, with a particular focus on lending to small and medium enterprises and on trade financing, including lending under official export credit insurance schemes.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p420 ft1">By 31 December 2016, the Commission shall, on the basis of these reports, submit a report, and if appropriate a legislative proposal to the European Parliament and Council.</P>
<P class="p31 ft8">Article 482</P>
<P class="p537 ft8">Leverage</P>
<P class="p33 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">1.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">The Commission shall submit by 31 December 2016 a report on the impact and effectiveness of the leverage ratio to the European Parliament and the Council. Where appropriate, the report shall be accompanied by a legislative proposal on the introduction of one or more levels for the leverage ratio that institutions would be required to meet, suggesting an adequate calibration for those levels and any appropriate adjustments to the capital measure and the total exposure measure as defined in Article 416.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p631 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">2.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">For the purposes of paragraph 1, the EBA shall report to the Commission by 31 October 2016 on at least the following:</SPAN></P>
<P class="p97 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(a)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft12">whether the requirements laid out in Articles 75 and 85 of Directive [inserted by OP] in accordance with Articles 72 and 92 of Directive [inserted by OP] for addressing the risk of excessive leverage ensure sound management of this risk by institutions and, if not, which further enhancement they need in order to ensure these objectives;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p433 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(b)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft11">whether – and if so, which - changes to the calculation methodology detailed in Article 416 would be necessary to ensure that the leverage ratio can be used as an appropriate indicator of an institutions risk of excessive leverage;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p21 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(c)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft12">whether, in the context of the calculation of the total exposure measure of the leverage ratio, the exposure value of items listed in Annex II and credit derivatives determined by using the Original Exposure Method differs in a material way from the exposure value determined by using the </SPAN><NOBR>Mark-to-Market</NOBR> Method;</P>
<P class="p22 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(d)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft11">whether using either own funds or Common Equity Tier 1 capital as the capital measure of the leverage ratio could be more appropriate for the intended purpose of tracking the risk of excessive leverage and, if so, what would be the appropriate calibration of the leverage ratio;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p632 ft1">149</P>
</DIV>
<DIV id="page_151">


<P class="p37 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(e)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft12">whether the 10% conversion factor for commitments that are unconditionally cancellable is appropriately conservative based on the evidence collected during the observation period;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p439 ft4"><SPAN class="ft1">(f)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft129">whether the frequency and format of the disclosure of items referred to in Article 436 are adequate;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p22 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(g)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft11">whether 3% would be an appropriate level for the leverage ratio based on Tier 1 capital and, if not, what level would be the appropriate one;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p21 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(h)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft11">whether introducing the leverage ratio as a requirement for institutions would necessitate any changes to the leverage ratio framework provided by this Regulation and, if so, which ones;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p34 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(i)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft30">whether introducing the leverage ratio as a requirement for institutions would effectively constrain the risk of excessive leverage on the part of those institutions and, if so, whether the level for the leverage ratio should be the same for all institutions or should differ for different types of institution and, in the latter case, what additional calibrations would be required.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p149 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">3.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">The report referred to in paragraph 2 shall cover at least the period from 1 January 2013 until 30 June 2016 and shall take account of at least the following:</SPAN></P>
<P class="p21 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(a)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft12">the impact of introducing the leverage ratio, determined in accordance with Article 416, as a requirement that institutions would have to meet on:</SPAN></P>
<P class="p287 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(i)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft14">financial markets in general and markets for repurchase transactions, derivatives and covered bonds in particular;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p60 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(ii)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft15">the robustness of institutions;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p60 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(iii)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft16">business models and </SPAN><NOBR>balance-sheet</NOBR> structures of institutions;</P>
<P class="p190 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(iv)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft55">the migration of exposures to entities which are not subject to prudential supervision;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p633 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(v)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft11">financial innovation, in particular the development of instruments with embedded leverage;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p60 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(vi)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft55">institutions' </SPAN><NOBR>risk-taking</NOBR> behaviour;</P>
<P class="p60 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(vii)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft131">clearing, settlement and custody activities;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p491 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(viii)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft132">cyclicality of the capital measure and the total exposure measure of the leverage ratio;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p634 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(ix)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft55">bank lending, with a particular focus on lending to small and medium enterprises and on trade financing, including lending under official export credit insurance schemes;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p635 ft1">150</P>
</DIV>
<DIV id="page_152">


<P class="p93 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(b)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft11">the interaction of the leverage ratio with the </SPAN><NOBR>risk-based</NOBR> own funds requirements and the liquidity requirements as specified in this Regulation;</P>
<P class="p21 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(c)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft12">the impact of accounting differences between accounting standards applicable under Regulation (EC) No 1606/2002, accounting standards applicable under Directive 86/635/EC and other relevant accounting standards on the comparability of the leverage ratio.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p44 ft8">Article 483</P>
<P class="p636 ft8">Exposures to transferred credit risk</P>
<P class="p47 ft1">By 31 December 2013 the Commission shall report to the European Parliament and the Council on the application and effectiveness of the provisions of Part Five in the light of international market developments.</P>
<P class="p14 ft8">Article 484</P>
<P class="p250 ft8">Counterparty Credit Risk and the Original Exposure Method</P>
<P class="p47 ft1">By 31 December 2016 the Commission shall review and report on the application of Article 270 and shall submit this report to the European Parliament and the Council, and, if appropriate, a legislative proposal.</P>
<P class="p14 ft8">Article 485</P>
<P class="p530 ft8">Retail exposures</P>
<P class="p47 ft1">The Commission shall within 24 months after the entry into force of this Regulation, report on the impact of the own funds requirements laid down in this Regulation on lending to small and medium- sized enterprises and natural persons and shall submit this report to the European Parliament and the Council, and, if appropriate, a legislative proposal.</P>
<P class="p637 ft1">For these purposes, EBA shall report the following to the Commission with regard to Article 118:</P>
<P class="p16 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(a)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft31">a comparison between actual unexpected credit losses on lending to small and medium sized enterprises and natural persons within the European Union over a full economic cycle and the unexpected credit losses based on the credit risk weights applicable to lending to small and </SPAN><NOBR>medium-sized</NOBR> enterprises;</P>
<P class="p18 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(b)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft31">an analysis whether the limit of EUR 1 million constrains the appropriate application of the </SPAN><NOBR>risk-weighting.</NOBR></P>
<P class="p95 ft8">Article 486</P>
<P class="p638 ft8">Definition of eligible capital</P>
<P class="p47 ft1">By 31 December 2013 the Commission shall review and report on the appropriateness of the definition of eligible capital being applied for the purposes of Title IV of Part Two and Part Four and shall submit this report to the European Parliament and the Council, and, if appropriate, a legislative proposal.</P>
<P class="p525 ft1">151</P>
</DIV>
<DIV id="page_153">


<P class="p463 ft1">152</P>
</DIV>
<DIV id="page_154">


<P class="p639 ft6">PART ELEVEN</P>
<P class="p640 ft6">FINAL PROVISIONS</P>
<P class="p341 ft8">Article 487</P>
<P class="p432 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">1.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">Subject to paragraph 2, this Regulation shall apply from 1 January 2013.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p107 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">2.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">Article 436(1) shall apply from 1 January 2015.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p161 ft8">Article 488</P>
<P class="p238 ft1">This Regulation shall enter into force on the day following that of its publication in the <SPAN class="ft8">Official Journal of the European Union</SPAN>.</P>
<P class="p641 ft1">This Regulation shall be binding in its entirety and directly applicable in all Member States.</P>
<P class="p510 ft1">Done at Brussels,</P>
<TABLE cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 class="t23">
<TR>
<TD class="tr19 td272"><P class="p9 ft8">For the European Parliament</P></TD>
<TD class="tr19 td273"><P class="p9 ft8">For the Council</P></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD class="tr2 td272"><P class="p9 ft8">The President</P></TD>
<TD class="tr2 td273"><P class="p9 ft8">The President</P></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P class="p642 ft1">153</P>
</DIV>
<DIV id="page_155">


<P class="p643 ft144">Annex I</P>
<P class="p156 ft144">Classification of <NOBR>Off-balance-sheet</NOBR> items</P>
<P class="p432 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">1.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">Full risk:</SPAN></P>
<P class="p107 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">–</SPAN><SPAN class="ft145">Guarantees having the character of credit substitutes,</SPAN></P>
<P class="p432 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">–</SPAN><SPAN class="ft145">Credit derivatives,</SPAN></P>
<P class="p107 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">–</SPAN><SPAN class="ft145">Acceptances,</SPAN></P>
<P class="p432 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">–</SPAN><SPAN class="ft145">Endorsements on bills not bearing the name of another institution,</SPAN></P>
<P class="p107 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">–</SPAN><SPAN class="ft145">Transactions with recourse,</SPAN></P>
<P class="p107 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">–</SPAN><SPAN class="ft145">Irrevocable standby letters of credit having the character of credit substitutes,</SPAN></P>
<P class="p432 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">–</SPAN><SPAN class="ft145">Assets purchased under outright forward purchase agreements,</SPAN></P>
<P class="p107 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">–</SPAN><SPAN class="ft145">Forward deposits,</SPAN></P>
<P class="p432 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">–</SPAN><SPAN class="ft145">The unpaid portion of </SPAN><NOBR>partly-paid</NOBR> shares and securities,</P>
<P class="p29 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">–</SPAN><SPAN class="ft145">Asset sale and repurchase agreements as defined in Article 12(3) and (5) of Directive 86/635/EEC,</SPAN></P>
<P class="p243 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">–</SPAN><SPAN class="ft145">Other items also carrying full risk.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p107 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">2.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">Medium risk:</SPAN></P>
<P class="p432 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">–</SPAN><SPAN class="ft145">Documentary credits issued and confirmed (see also Medium/low risk),</SPAN></P>
<P class="p16 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">–</SPAN><SPAN class="ft145">Warranties and indemnities (including tender, performance, customs and tax bonds) and guarantees not having the character of credit substitutes,</SPAN></P>
<P class="p107 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">–</SPAN><SPAN class="ft145">Irrevocable standby letters of credit not having the character of credit substitutes,</SPAN></P>
<P class="p29 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">–</SPAN><SPAN class="ft145">Undrawn credit facilities (agreements to lend, purchase securities, provide guarantees or acceptance facilities) with an original maturity of more than one year,</SPAN></P>
<P class="p107 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">–</SPAN><SPAN class="ft145">Note issuance facilities (NIFs) and revolving underwriting facilities (RUFs),</SPAN></P>
<P class="p107 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">–</SPAN><SPAN class="ft145">Other items also carrying medium risk and as communicated to EBA.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p432 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">3.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">Medium/low risk:</SPAN></P>
<P class="p16 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">–</SPAN><SPAN class="ft145">Documentary credits in which underlying shipment acts as collateral and other </SPAN><NOBR>self-liquidating</NOBR> transactions,</P>
<P class="p16 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">–</SPAN><SPAN class="ft145">Undrawn credit facilities which comprise agreements to lend, purchase securities, provide guarantees or acceptance facilities with an original maturity of up to and including one year which may not be cancelled unconditionally at any time without notice or that do not</SPAN></P>
<P class="p502 ft1">154</P>
</DIV>
<DIV id="page_156">


<P class="p471 ft1">effectively provide for automatic cancellation due to deterioration in a borrower's creditworthiness,</P>
<P class="p243 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">–</SPAN><SPAN class="ft145">Other items also carrying medium/low risk and as communicated to EBA.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p107 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">4.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">Low risk:</SPAN></P>
<P class="p33 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">–</SPAN><SPAN class="ft145">Undrawn credit facilities comprising agreements to lend, purchase securities, provide guarantees or acceptance facilities which may be cancelled unconditionally at any time without notice, or that do effectively provide for automatic cancellation due to deterioration in a borrower's creditworthiness. Retail credit lines may be considered as unconditionally cancellable if the terms permit the institution to cancel them to the full extent allowable under consumer protection and related legislation; and</SPAN></P>
<P class="p473 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">–</SPAN><SPAN class="ft145">Other items also carrying low risk and as communicated to EBA.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p644 ft1">155</P>
</DIV>
<DIV id="page_157">


<P class="p537 ft144">Annex II</P>
<P class="p372 ft144">Types of derivatives</P>
<P class="p432 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">1.</SPAN><NOBR><SPAN class="ft9">Interest-rate</SPAN></NOBR> contracts:</P>
<P class="p94 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(a)</SPAN><NOBR><SPAN class="ft12">single-currency</SPAN></NOBR> interest rate swaps;</P>
<P class="p202 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(b)</SPAN><NOBR><SPAN class="ft11">basis-swaps;</SPAN></NOBR></P>
<P class="p94 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(c)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft12">forward rate agreements;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p202 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(d)</SPAN><NOBR><SPAN class="ft11">interest-rate</SPAN></NOBR> futures;</P>
<P class="p94 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(e)</SPAN><NOBR><SPAN class="ft12">interest-rate</SPAN></NOBR> options purchased;</P>
<P class="p94 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(f)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft30">other contracts of similar nature.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p432 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">2.</SPAN><NOBR><SPAN class="ft9">Foreign-exchange</SPAN></NOBR> contracts and contracts concerning gold:</P>
<P class="p94 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(a)</SPAN><NOBR><SPAN class="ft12">cross-currency</SPAN></NOBR> <NOBR>interest-rate</NOBR> swaps;</P>
<P class="p202 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(b)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft11">forward </SPAN><NOBR>foreign-exchange</NOBR> contracts;</P>
<P class="p94 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(c)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft12">currency futures;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p94 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(d)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft11">currency options purchased;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p202 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(e)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft12">other contracts of a similar nature;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p94 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(f)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft30">contracts of a nature similar to (a) to (e) concerning gold.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p33 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">3.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">Contracts of a nature similar to those in points 1(a) to (e) and 2(a) to (d) concerning other reference items or indices. This includes as a minimum all instruments specified in points 4 to 7, 9 and 10 of Section C of Annex I to Directive 2004/39/EC not otherwise included in points 1 or 2.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p645 ft1">156</P>
</DIV>
<DIV id="page_158">


<P class="p646 ft144">Annex III</P>
<P class="p647 ft144">Items subject to supplementary reporting of liquid assets</P>
<P class="p432 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">1.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">cash;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p107 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">2.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">central bank reserves, to the extent that these reserves can be drawn down in times of stress;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p33 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">3.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">transferable securities representing claims on or claims guaranteed by sovereigns, central banks, public sector entities, regional governments and local authorities, the Bank for International Settlements, the International Monetary Fund, the European Commission, or multilateral development banks and satisfying all of the following conditions:</SPAN></P>
<P class="p30 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(a)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft12">they are assigned a 0% </SPAN><NOBR>risk-weight</NOBR> under Section 2 of Title III, Chapter 2;</P>
<P class="p39 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(b)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft11">they are traded in large, deep and active repurchase agreement or cash markets characterized by a low level of concentration;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p21 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(c)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft12">they have a proven record as a reliable source of liquidity by either repurchase agreement or sale even during stressed market conditions;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p191 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(d)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft11">they are not an obligation of an institution or any of its affiliated entities.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p33 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">4.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">transferable securities other than those referred to in point (3) representing claims on or claims guaranteed by sovereigns or central banks issued in domestic currencies by the sovereign or central bank in the currency and country in which the liquidity risk is being taken or issued in foreign currencies, to the extent that holding of such debt matches the liquidity needs of the banks operations in that third country;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p119 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">5.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">transferable securities representing claims on or claims guaranteed by sovereigns, central banks, public sector entities, regional governments and local authorities, or multilateral development banks and satisfying all of the following conditions.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p191 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(a)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft12">they are assigned a 20% </SPAN><NOBR>risk-weight</NOBR> under Section 2 of Title III, Chapter 2;</P>
<P class="p21 ft4"><SPAN class="ft1">(b)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft13">they are traded in large, deep and active repurchase agreement or cash markets characterized by a low level of concentration;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p22 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(c)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft12">they have a proven record as a reliable source of liquidity by either repurchase agreement or sale even during stressed market conditions;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p94 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(d)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft11">they are not an obligation of an institution or any of its affiliated entities.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p16 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">6.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">transferable securities other than those referred to in points (3) to (5) that qualify for a 20% or better risk weight under Section 2 of Title III, Chapter 2 or are internally rated as having an equivalent credit quality, and fulfil any of the following conditions:</SPAN></P>
<P class="p191 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(a)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft12">they do not represent a claim on an SSPE, an institution or any of its affiliated entities;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p39 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(b)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft11">they are bonds as defined in Article 22(4) of Directive 85/611/EEC qualify for the treatment in Article 124</SPAN></P>
<P class="p518 ft1">157</P>
</DIV>
<DIV id="page_159">


<P class="p646 ft144">Annex IV</P>
<P class="p648 ft144"><NOBR>Risk-adjusted</NOBR> assets and <NOBR>off-balance</NOBR> sheet items for the temporary capital ratio</P>
<P class="p100 ft2">Part 1 - Definitions</P>
<P class="p16 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">1.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">"Zone A" comprises all the Member States and all other countries which are full members of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) and those countries which have concluded special lending arrangements with the International Monetary Fund (IMF) associated with the Fund's general arrangements to borrow (GAB). Any country which reschedules its external sovereign debt is, however, precluded from Zone A for a period of five years;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p20 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">2.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">"Zone B" comprises all countries not in Zone A;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p16 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">3.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">"Zone A credit institutions" means all credit institutions authorised in the Member States, including their branches in third countries, and all credit institutions authorised in other Zone A countries, including their branches;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p218 ft4"><SPAN class="ft1">4.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft17">"Zone B credit institutions" means all credit institutions authorised outside Zone A, including their branches within the Union;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p486 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">5.</SPAN><NOBR><SPAN class="ft9">"non-bank</SPAN></NOBR> sector" means all borrowers other than credit institutions, central governments and central banks, regional governments and local authorities, the European Union, the European Investment Bank (EIB) and multilateral development banks;</P>
<P class="p38 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">6.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">multilateral development banks referred to in Article 112.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p510 ft2">Part 2 - <NOBR>Risk-adjusted</NOBR> assets and <NOBR>off-balance-sheet</NOBR> items</P>
<P class="p33 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">7.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">Degrees of credit risk, expressed as percentage weightings, shall be assigned to asset items in accordance with Part 3 and 4, and exceptionally Part 5. The </SPAN><NOBR>balance-sheet</NOBR> value of each asset shall then be multiplied by the relevant weighting to produce a <NOBR>risk-adjusted</NOBR> value.</P>
<P class="p18 ft4"><SPAN class="ft1">8.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft17">In the case of the </SPAN><NOBR>off-balance-sheet</NOBR> items listed in Annex I, a <NOBR>two-stage</NOBR> calculation as prescribed in Point 17 shall be used.</P>
<P class="p119 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">9.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">In the case of the </SPAN><NOBR>off-balance-sheet</NOBR> items referred to in Point 17, the potential costs of replacing contracts in the event of counterparty default shall be calculated by means of one of the two methods set out in Annex II. Those costs shall be multiplied by the relevant counterparty weightings in points <NOBR>11-15,</NOBR> except the 100 % weightings as provided for there shall be replaced by 50 % weightings to produce <NOBR>risk-adjusted</NOBR> values.</P>
<P class="p486 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">10.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft35">The total of the </SPAN><NOBR>risk-adjusted</NOBR> values of the assets and <NOBR>off-balance-sheet</NOBR> items mentioned in points 8 and 9 shall be the denominator of the solvency ratio.</P>
<P class="p510 ft2">Part 3 - Risk weightings</P>
<P class="p16 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">11.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft35">The following weightings shall be applied to the various categories of asset items, although the competent authorities may fix higher weightings as they see fit:</SPAN></P>
<P class="p107 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">12.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft35">Zero weighting</SPAN></P>
<P class="p649 ft1">158</P>
</DIV>
<DIV id="page_160">


<P class="p411 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(a)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft12">cash in hand and equivalent items;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p202 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(b)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft11">asset items constituting claims on Zone A central governments and central banks;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p94 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(c)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft12">asset items constituting claims on the European Union;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p21 ft4"><SPAN class="ft1">(d)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft13">asset items constituting claims carrying the explicit guarantees of Zone A central governments and central banks or of the European Union;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p22 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(e)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft12">asset items constituting claims on Zone B central governments and central banks denominated and funded in the national currencies of the borrowers;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p21 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(f)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft30">asset items constituting claims carrying the explicit guarantees of Zone B central governments and central banks denominated and funded in the national currency common to the guarantor and the borrower;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p35 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(g)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft11">asset items secured to the satisfaction of the competent authorities, by collateral in the form of Zone A central government or central bank securities or securities issued by the European Union or by cash deposits placed with the lending institution or by certificates of deposit or similar instruments issued by and lodged with the latter;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p38 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">13.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft35">20% weighting</SPAN></P>
<P class="p94 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(a)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft12">asset items constituting claims on the EIB;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p202 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(b)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft11">asset items constituting claims on multilateral development banks;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p94 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(c)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft12">asset items constituting claims carrying the explicit guarantee of the EIB;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p21 ft4"><SPAN class="ft1">(d)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft13">asset items constituting claims carrying the explicit guarantees of multilateral development banks;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p22 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(e)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft12">asset items constituting claims on Zone A regional governments or local authorities, subject to Part 4;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p97 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(f)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft30">asset items constituting claims carrying the explicit guarantees of Zone A regional governments or local authorities, subject to Part 4;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p21 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(g)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft11">asset items constituting claims on Zone A credit institutions but not constituting such institutions' own funds;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p40 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(h)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft11">asset items constituting claims with a maturity of one year or less, on Zone B credit institutions, other than securities issued by such institutions which are recognised as components of their own funds;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p94 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(i)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft30">asset items carrying the explicit guarantees of Zone A credit institutions;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p21 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(j)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft30">asset items constituting claims with a maturity of one year or less carrying the explicit guarantees of Zone B credit institutions;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p21 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(k)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft11">asset items secured, to the satisfaction of the competent authorities, by collateral in the form of securities issued by the EIB or by multilateral development banks;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p554 ft1">159</P>
</DIV>
<DIV id="page_161">


<P class="p411 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(l)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft30">cash items in the process of collection;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p432 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">14.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft35">50% weighting</SPAN></P>
<P class="p21 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(a)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft12">loans fully and completely secured, to the satisfaction of the competent authorities, by mortgages on residential property which is or will be occupied or let by the borrower, and loans fully and completely secured, to the satisfaction of the competent authorities, by shares in Finnish residential housing companies, operating in accordance with the Finnish Housing Company Act of 1991 or subsequent equivalent legislation, in respect of residential property which is or will be occupied or let by the borrower;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p57 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(b)</SPAN><NOBR><SPAN class="ft11">"mortgage-backed</SPAN></NOBR> securities" which may be treated as loans referred to in point (a), if the competent authorities consider, having regard to the legal framework in force in each Member State, that they are equivalent in the light of the credit risk. Without prejudice to the types of securities which may be included in and are capable of fulfilling the conditions in this point 1, <NOBR>"mortgage-backed</NOBR> securities" may include instruments within the meaning of Annex I C (1) and C (3) of Directive 2004/39/EC. The competent authorities must in particular be satisfied that:</P>
<P class="p650 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(i)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft14">such securities are fully and directly backed by a pool of mortgages which are of the same nature as those defined in point (a) and are fully performing when the </SPAN><NOBR>mortgage-backed</NOBR> securities are created;</P>
<P class="p235 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(ii)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft15">an acceptable </SPAN><NOBR>high-priority</NOBR> charge on the underlying <NOBR>mortgage-asset</NOBR> items is held either directly by investors in <NOBR>mortgage-backed</NOBR> securities or on their behalf by a trustee or mandated representative in the same proportion to the securities which they hold;</P>
<P class="p34 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(c)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft12">prepayments and accrued income: these assets shall be subject to the weighting corresponding to the counterparty where a credit institution is able to determine it in accordance with Directive 86/635/EEC. Otherwise, where it is unable to determine the counterparty, it shall apply a </SPAN><NOBR>flat-rate</NOBR> weighting of 50%;</P>
<P class="p113 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">15.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft35">100% weighting</SPAN></P>
<P class="p159 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(a)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft12">asset items constituting claims on Zone B central governments and central banks except where denominated and funded in the national currency of the borrower;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p94 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(b)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft11">asset items constituting claims on Zone B regional governments or local authorities;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p21 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(c)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft12">asset items constituting claims with a maturity of more than one year on Zone B credit institutions;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p94 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(d)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft11">asset items constituting claims on the Zone A and Zone B </SPAN><NOBR>non-bank</NOBR> sectors;</P>
<P class="p94 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(e)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft12">tangible "Assets" within the meaning of Article 4(10) of Directive 86/635/EEC;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p39 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(f)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft30">holdings of shares, participation and other components of the own funds of other credit institutions which are not deducted from the own funds of the lending institutions;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p191 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(g)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft11">all other assets except where deducted from own funds.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p593 ft1">160</P>
</DIV>
<DIV id="page_162">


<P class="p193 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">16.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft35">The following treatment shall apply to </SPAN><NOBR>off-balance-sheet</NOBR> items other than those covered in point 17. They shall first be grouped according to the risk groupings set out in Annex II. The full value of the <NOBR>full-risk</NOBR> items shall be taken into account, 50% of the value of the medium- risk items and 20% of the <NOBR>medium/low-risk</NOBR> items, while the value of <NOBR>low-risk</NOBR> items shall be set at zero. The second stage shall be to multiply the <NOBR>off-balance-sheet</NOBR> values, adjusted as described above, by the weightings attributable to the relevant counterparties in accordance with the treatment of asset items prescribed in points <NOBR>11-15</NOBR> and Part 4. In the case of asset sale and repurchase agreements and outright forward purchases, the weightings shall be those attaching to the assets in question and not to the counterparties to the transactions. The portion of unpaid capital subscribed to the European Investment Fund may be weighted at 20%.</P>
<P class="p151 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">17.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft35">The methods set out in Annex II shall be applied to the </SPAN><NOBR>off-balance-sheet</NOBR> items listed in Annex I except for:</P>
<P class="p94 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(a)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft12">contracts traded on recognised exchanges,</SPAN></P>
<P class="p21 ft4"><SPAN class="ft1">(b)</SPAN><NOBR><SPAN class="ft13">foreign-exchange</SPAN></NOBR> contracts (except contracts concerning gold) with an original maturity of 14 calendar days or less.</P>
<P class="p119 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">18.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft35">Where </SPAN><NOBR>off-balance-sheet</NOBR> items carry explicit guarantees, they shall be weighted as if they had been incurred on behalf of the guarantor rather than the counterparty. Where the potential exposure arising from <NOBR>off-balance-sheet</NOBR> transactions is fully and completely secured, to the satisfaction of the competent authorities, by any of the asset items recognised as collateral in points 12(g) and 13(k), weightings of zero or 20 % shall apply depending on the collateral in question.</P>
<P class="p149 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">19.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft35">The Member States may apply a 50% weighting to </SPAN><NOBR>off-balance-sheet</NOBR> items which are sureties or guarantees having the character of credit substitutes and which are fully guaranteed, to the satisfaction of the competent authorities, by mortgages meeting the conditions set out in point 14(a), subject to the guarantor having a direct right to such collateral.</P>
<P class="p119 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">20.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft35">Where asset and </SPAN><NOBR>off-balance-sheet</NOBR> items are given a lower weighting because of the existence of explicit guarantees or collateral acceptable to the competent authorities, the lower weighting shall apply only to that part which is guaranteed or which is fully covered by the collateral.</P>
<P class="p651 ft2">Part 4 - Weighting of claims for regional governments or local authorities of the Member States</P>
<P class="p33 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">21.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft35">Notwithstanding the requirements of point 13, the Member States may fix a weighting of zero for their own regional governments and local authorities if there is no difference in risk between claims on the latter and claims on their central governments because of the revenue- raising powers of the regional governments and local authorities and the existence of specific institutional arrangements the effect of which is to reduce the chances of default by the latter. A </SPAN><NOBR>zero-weighting</NOBR> fixed in accordance with these criteria shall apply to claims on and off- <NOBR>balance-sheet</NOBR> items incurred on behalf of the regional governments and local authorities in question and claims on others and <NOBR>off-balance-sheet</NOBR> items incurred on behalf of others and guaranteed by those regional governments and local authorities or secured, to the satisfaction of the competent authorities concerned, by collateral in the form of securities issued by those regional governments or local authorities.</P>
<P class="p652 ft1">161</P>
</DIV>
<DIV id="page_163">


<P class="p193 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">22.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft35">The Member States shall notify EBA if they believe a </SPAN><NOBR>zero-weighting</NOBR> to be justified according to the criteria laid down in point 21. Other Member States may offer the credit institutions under the supervision of their competent authorities the possibility of applying a zero- weighting where they undertake business with the regional governments or local authorities in question or where they hold claims guaranteed by the latter, including collateral in the form of securities.</P>
<P class="p653 ft2">Part 5 - Other weighting</P>
<P class="p33 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">23.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft35">Without prejudice to point 21, the Member States may apply a weighting of 20% to asset items which are secured, to the satisfaction of the competent authorities concerned, by collateral in the form of securities issued by Zone A regional governments or local authorities, by deposits placed with Zone A credit institutions other than the lending institution, or by certificates of deposit or similar instruments issued by such credit institutions.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p119 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">24.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft35">The Member States may apply a weighting of 10% to claims on institutions specialising in the </SPAN><NOBR>inter-bank</NOBR> and <NOBR>public-debt</NOBR> markets in their home Member States and subject to close supervision by the competent authorities where those asset items are fully and completely secured, to the satisfaction of the competent authorities of the home Member States, by a combination of asset items mentioned in points 12 and 13 recognised by the latter as constituting adequate collateral.</P>
<P class="p145 ft4"><SPAN class="ft1">25.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft146">The Member States shall notify EBA of any provisions adopted pursuant to points 23 and 24 and of the grounds for such provisions.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p654 ft2">Part 6 - Administrative bodies and <NOBR>non-commercial</NOBR> undertakings</P>
<P class="p33 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">26.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft35">For the purposes of point 13, the competent authorities may include within the concept of regional governments and local authorities </SPAN><NOBR>non-commercial</NOBR> administrative bodies responsible to regional governments or local authorities or authorities which, in the view of the competent authorities, exercise the same responsibilities as regional and local authorities.</P>
<P class="p119 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">27.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft35">The competent authorities may also include within the concept of regional governments and local authorities, churches and religious communities constituted in the form of a legal person under public law, in so far as they raise taxes in accordance with legislation conferring on them the right to do so. However, in this case the options set out in Part 4 shall not apply.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p655 ft1">162</P>
</DIV>
<DIV id="page_164">

<DIV id="id_1">
<P class="p428 ft144">LEGISLATIVE FINANCIAL STATEMENT FOR PROPOSALS</P>
<P class="p473 ft2"><SPAN class="ft2">1.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft148">FRAMEWORK OF THE PROPOSAL/INITIATIVE</SPAN></P>
<P class="p432 ft2"><SPAN class="ft2">1.1.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft151">Title of the proposal/initiative</SPAN></P>
<P class="p668 ft4">Proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on prudential requirements for credit institutions and investment firms</P>
<P class="p113 ft2"><SPAN class="ft2">1.2.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft151">Policy area(s) concerned in the ABM/ABB structure</SPAN><SPAN class="ft152">1</SPAN></P>
<P class="p669 ft153">Internal Market – financial markets Internal Market – financial institutions</P>
<P class="p670 ft2"><SPAN class="ft2">1.3.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft151">Nature of the proposal/initiative</SPAN></P>
<P class="p56 ft154"><SPAN class="ft39">: </SPAN>The proposal/initiative relates to <SPAN class="ft33">a new action</SPAN></P>
<P class="p671 ft33"><SPAN class="ft154">The proposal/initiative relates to </SPAN>a new action following a pilot project/preparatory action<SPAN class="ft155">2</SPAN></P>
<P class="p672 ft1">The proposal/initiative relates to <SPAN class="ft2">the extension of an existing action</SPAN></P>
<P class="p671 ft33"><SPAN class="ft154">The proposal/initiative relates to </SPAN>an action redirected towards a new action</P>
<P class="p432 ft2"><SPAN class="ft2">1.4.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft151">Objectives</SPAN></P>
<P class="p432 ft8"><SPAN class="ft8">1.4.1.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft156">The Commission's multiannual strategic objective(s) targeted by the proposal/initiative</SPAN></P>
<P class="p668 ft1">First and foremost, this initiative is linked to the strategic objective of improving the regulation and supervision of financial markets. The unprecedented level of fiscal support to banks needs to be matched with a robust reform addressing the regulatory shortcomings exposed during the financial crisis. This reform of EU bank regulation reflects the outcome of internationally coordinated work on the Basel III bank capital and liquidity framework and is aligned with another strategic objective of setting global standards through cooperation and agreement with international partners.</P>
<P class="p213 ft8"><SPAN class="ft8">1.4.2.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft156">Specific objective(s) and ABM/ABB activity(ies) concerned</SPAN></P>
<P class="p291 ft1"><SPAN class="ft60">Specific objective No</SPAN>.1. (Internal Market – financial institutions)</P>
<P class="p673 ft153">Improve the capital requirements regime of the banking, insurance and pension sectors <SPAN class="ft157">Specific objective No</SPAN>.1. (Internal Market – financial markets)</P>
</DIV>
<DIV id="id_2">
<DIV id="id_2_1">
<P class="p463 ft61">1</P>
<P class="p674 ft61">2</P>
</DIV>
<DIV id="id_2_2">
<P class="p463 ft158">ABM: <NOBR>Activity-Based</NOBR> Management – ABB: <NOBR>Activity-Based</NOBR> Budgeting. As referred to in Article 49(6)(a) or (b) of the Financial Regulation.</P>
</DIV>
</DIV>
<DIV id="id_3">
<P class="p463 ft1">211</P>
</DIV>
</DIV>
<DIV id="page_213">
<DIV id="dimg1">
<INGENBILD zsrc="GZB6452213x1.jpg/" id="img1">
</DIV>


<DIV class="dclr"></DIV>
<P class="p675 ft1">Promote stability and integrity in financial markets through adequate supervision, robust market infrastructures and a high level of transparency</P>
<P class="p676 ft1">In addition to the above two specific objectives identified in the MARKT management plan for 2011, the initiative is geared towards contributing to the following specific objectives which have been identified in the impact assessments accompanying the proposals:</P>
<P class="p677 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">-</SPAN><SPAN class="ft89">enhancing bank risk management;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p678 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">-</SPAN><SPAN class="ft89">preventing regulatory arbitrage opportunities;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p679 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">-</SPAN><SPAN class="ft89">enhancing legal clarity;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p679 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">-</SPAN><SPAN class="ft89">reducing compliance burden;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p678 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">-</SPAN><SPAN class="ft89">enhancing level playing field;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p679 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">-</SPAN><SPAN class="ft89">enhancing supervisory cooperation and convergence;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p680 ft161"><SPAN class="ft1">-</SPAN><SPAN class="ft159">reducing the cyclicality of bank lending; </SPAN><SPAN class="ft160">ABM/ABB activity(ies) concerned </SPAN>Financial markets, financial institutions</P>
<P class="p681 ft1">212</P>
</DIV>
<DIV id="page_214">
<DIV id="dimg1">
<INGENBILD zsrc="GZB6452214x1.jpg/" id="img1">
</DIV>


<P class="p413 ft8"><SPAN class="ft8">1.4.3.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft156">Expected result(s) and impact</SPAN></P>
<P class="p205 ft96">Specify the effects which the proposal/initiative should have on the beneficiaries/groups targeted.</P>
<P class="p682 ft1">The proposals should lead to enhanced capitalisation and improved liquidity risk management of the EU banking sector. In turn, this should lead to the lower frequency of systemic banking crises in the future. The enhanced financial stability is expected to yield concomitant net economic benefits of annual increase in the EU GDP in the range of <NOBR>0.3%-2%.</NOBR> These benefits will accrue to a wide range of stakeholders, including individual, SME and large corporate bank borrowers and creditors, governments, and the EU citizens in general.</P>
<P class="p298 ft1">The European Banking Authority (EBA) will play an important role in order to achieve these results, as the proposals ask it to develop some 50+ binding technical standards (BTS) on various policy issues. BTS – which would eventually be endorsed by the Commission – will be key to ensure that provisions of highly technical nature are implemented uniformly across the EU and that the proposed policies work as intended. EBA's work, therefore, should contribute to the effective attainment of the relevant strategic and specific objectives outlined in sections 1.4.1 and 1.4.2.</P>
<P class="p213 ft8"><SPAN class="ft8">1.4.4.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft156">Indicators of results and impact</SPAN></P>
<P class="p205 ft96">Specify the indicators for monitoring implementation of the proposal/initiative.</P>
<P class="p683 ft1">1. Expected results:</P>
<P class="p94 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">-</SPAN><SPAN class="ft89">enhanced financial stability via improved regulation and supervision of banks;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p684 ft153"><SPAN class="ft1">-</SPAN><SPAN class="ft162">improved EU bank capitalisation and enhanced liquidity risk management. Indicators:</SPAN></P>
<P class="p685 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">-</SPAN><SPAN class="ft89">dynamics of the cost of protection against default of financial institutions;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p202 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">-</SPAN><SPAN class="ft89">percentage of banks successfully passing EU stress tests;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p686 ft153"><SPAN class="ft1">-</SPAN><SPAN class="ft162">capital ratios and capital buffers above the capital requirement, held by the EU banks. 2. Expected result:</SPAN></P>
<P class="p687 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">-</SPAN><SPAN class="ft89">enhanced effectiveness of the EU bank regulation and supervision</SPAN></P>
<P class="p205 ft1">Indicator:</P>
<P class="p202 ft1">- number of binding technical standards developed by EBA on time</P>
<P class="p688 ft2"><SPAN class="ft2">1.5.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft151">Grounds for the proposal/initiative</SPAN></P>
<P class="p107 ft8"><SPAN class="ft8">1.5.1.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft156">Requirement(s) to be met in the short or long term</SPAN></P>
<P class="p689 ft1">Based on the two proposals, some 60% of the BTS that EBA is asked to prepare will be due in 2013 which requires an increase in its FTE count in order for it to handle the workload. The</P>
<P class="p690 ft1">213</P>
</DIV>
<DIV id="page_215">
<DIV id="dimg1">
<INGENBILD zsrc="GZB6452215x1.jpg/" id="img1">
</DIV>


<P class="p148 ft1">increase in the FTEs will need to be sustained in the subsequent years to amend the already developed BTS and to prepare the remaining 40% of the BTS. Also, in the long run, additional BTS <NOBR>development-related</NOBR> work will come from future legislative proposals in the area of EU banking regulation.</P>
<P class="p432 ft8"><SPAN class="ft8">1.5.2.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft156">Added value of EU involvement</SPAN></P>
<P class="p691 ft1">There are several major justifications for the added value of EU involvement through this initiative. They include:</P>
<P class="p94 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">-</SPAN><SPAN class="ft89">a need to enhance the integration of the EU internal banking market;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p23 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">-</SPAN><SPAN class="ft132">address several market and regulatory failures that were brought to light by the financial crisis;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p692 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">-</SPAN><SPAN class="ft163">correct for regulatory arbitrage opportunities which are made possible by the current legislation; and</SPAN></P>
<P class="p24 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">-</SPAN><SPAN class="ft132">ensure a consistent EU approach for tackling various issues covered by the scope of the initiative, which would do away with the need for Member States to pursue individual approaches that risk fragmenting the Internal Market.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p17 ft1">Most importantly, only a common <NOBR>EU-level</NOBR> approach could be expected to effectively provide for financial stability and tame excessive financial <NOBR>pro-cyclicality,</NOBR> as currently policies that are directed toward these key systemic aspects are either geared to national needs or are absent altogether.</P>
<P class="p693 ft8"><SPAN class="ft8">1.5.3.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft156">Lessons learned from similar experiences in the past</SPAN></P>
<P class="p691 ft1">As regards BTS, 2011 is a first year of operation of EBA. Therefore, first sets of BTS that are linked to the existing legislative framework are yet to be delivered to the Commission.</P>
<P class="p688 ft8"><SPAN class="ft8">1.5.4.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft156">Coherence and possible synergy with other relevant instruments</SPAN></P>
<P class="p691 ft1">The proposal is coherent with regulation with the Regulation (EU) No 1093/2010 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 24 November 2010 establishing a European Supervisory Authority (European Banking Authority)</P>
<P class="p694 ft1">214</P>
</DIV>
<DIV id="page_216">
<DIV id="dimg1">
<INGENBILD zsrc="GZB6452216x1.jpg/" id="img1">
</DIV>


<P class="p695 ft2"><SPAN class="ft2">1.6.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft151">Duration and financial impact</SPAN></P>
<P class="p696 ft1">Proposal/initiative of <SPAN class="ft2">limited duration</SPAN></P>
<P class="p697 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">–</SPAN><SPAN class="ft164">Proposal/initiative in effect from [DD/MM]YYYY to [DD/MM]YYYY</SPAN></P>
<P class="p698 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">–</SPAN><SPAN class="ft164">Financial impact from YYYY to YYYY</SPAN></P>
<P class="p699 ft1"><SPAN class="ft39">: </SPAN>Proposal/initiative of <SPAN class="ft2">unlimited duration</SPAN></P>
<P class="p697 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">–</SPAN><SPAN class="ft165">Implementation with a </SPAN><NOBR>start-up</NOBR> period from YYYY to YYYY,</P>
<P class="p697 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">–</SPAN><SPAN class="ft165">followed by </SPAN><NOBR>full-scale</NOBR> operation.</P>
<P class="p700 ft2"><SPAN class="ft2">1.7.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft151">Management mode(s) envisaged</SPAN><SPAN class="ft152">3</SPAN></P>
<P class="p701 ft2">Centralised direct management <SPAN class="ft1">by the Commission</SPAN></P>
<P class="p696 ft1"><SPAN class="ft2">Centralised indirect management </SPAN>with the delegation of implementation tasks to:</P>
<P class="p697 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">–</SPAN><SPAN class="ft164">executive agencies</SPAN></P>
<P class="p702 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">–</SPAN><SPAN class="ft166">: </SPAN>bodies set up by the Communities<SPAN class="ft58">4</SPAN></P>
<P class="p703 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">–</SPAN><SPAN class="ft164">national </SPAN><NOBR>public-sector</NOBR> bodies/bodies with <NOBR>public-service</NOBR> mission</P>
<P class="p704 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">–</SPAN><SPAN class="ft167">persons entrusted with the implementation of specific actions pursuant to Title V of the Treaty on European Union and identified in the relevant basic act within the meaning of Article 49 of the Financial Regulation</SPAN></P>
<P class="p705 ft1"><SPAN class="ft2">Shared management </SPAN>with the Member States</P>
<P class="p706 ft2">Decentralised management <SPAN class="ft1">with third countries</SPAN></P>
<P class="p696 ft1"><SPAN class="ft2">Joint management </SPAN>with international organisations <SPAN class="ft168">(to be specified)</SPAN></P>
<P class="p707 ft169">If more than one management mode is indicated, please provide details in the "Comments" section.</P>
<P class="p708 ft1">Comments</P>
<P class="p709 ft172"><SPAN class="ft48">3</SPAN><SPAN class="ft170">Details of management modes and references to the Financial Regulation may be found on the BudgWeb site: </SPAN><A href="http://www.cc.cec/budg/man/budgmanag/budgmanag_en.html"><SPAN class="ft171">http://www.cc.cec/budg/man/budgmanag/budgmanag_en.html</SPAN></A></P>
<P class="p695 ft172"><SPAN class="ft48">4</SPAN><SPAN class="ft170">As referred to in Article 185 of the Financial Regulation.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p108 ft1">215</P>
</DIV>
<DIV id="page_217">
<DIV id="dimg1">
<INGENBILD zsrc="GZB6452217x1.jpg/" id="img1">
</DIV>


<P class="p413 ft2"><SPAN class="ft2">2.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft148">MANAGEMENT MEASURES</SPAN></P>
<P class="p107 ft2"><SPAN class="ft2">2.1.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft151">Monitoring and reporting rules</SPAN></P>
<P class="p56 ft96">Specify frequency and conditions.</P>
<P class="p710 ft1">According to Article 81 of the Regulation (EU) No 1093/2010, by 2 January 2014, and every three years thereafter, the Commission shall publish a general report on the experience acquired as a result of the operation of EBA and the procedures laid down in the Regulation. That report shall evaluate, inter alia, the degree of convergence in supervisory practices reached by national supervisors and whether resources of EBA are adequate to carry out its responsibilities. The report would be forwarded to the European Parliament and to the Council.</P>
<P class="p473 ft2"><SPAN class="ft2">2.2.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft151">Management and control system</SPAN></P>
<P class="p432 ft8"><SPAN class="ft8">2.2.1.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft156">Risk(s) identified</SPAN></P>
<P class="p710 ft1">Three impact assessments have been conducted concerning the two proposals, identifying costs and benefits of different policy options to address the identified problems.</P>
<P class="p17 ft1">With respect to the responsibilities of EBA, there is a risk that effectiveness of the proposed rules is undermined by its inability – due to the lack of human resources - to deliver the BTS of high quality and in line with the dates set out in the Commission's proposal.</P>
<P class="p432 ft8"><SPAN class="ft8">2.2.2.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft156">Control method(s) envisaged</SPAN></P>
<P class="p710 ft1">Management and control systems of EBA are outlined in Chapter III of the Regulation (EU) No 1093/2010</P>
<P class="p24 ft1">Also, as mentioned under section 2.1, under Article 81 of this regulation, the Commission will be expected to publish every three years a report on the experience acquired as a result of the operation of EBA and the procedures laid down in the Regulation.</P>
<P class="p432 ft2"><SPAN class="ft2">2.3.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft151">Measures to prevent fraud and irregularities</SPAN></P>
<P class="p205 ft96">Specify existing or envisaged prevention and protection measures.</P>
<P class="p682 ft1">According to Article 66 of the Regulation (EU) No 1093/2010, for the purposes of combating fraud, corruption and any other illegal activity, Regulation (EC) No 1073/1999 shall apply to EBA without any restriction. EBA shall accede to the <NOBR>Inter-institutional</NOBR> Agreement concerning internal investigations by OLAF and shall immediately adopt appropriate provisions for all staff of EBA.</P>
<P class="p451 ft1">The funding decisions and the agreements and the implementing instruments resulting from them shall explicitly stipulate that the Court of Auditors and OLAF may, if need be, carry out <NOBR>on-the-spot</NOBR> checks on the beneficiaries of monies disbursed by the EBA as well as on the staff responsible for allocating these monies.</P>
<P class="p525 ft1">216</P>
</DIV>
<DIV id="page_218">
<DIV id="dimg1">
<INGENBILD zsrc="GZB6452218x1.jpg/" id="img1">
</DIV>

<DIV id="id_1">
<P class="p413 ft8"><SPAN class="ft8">3.2.2.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft156">Estimated impact on operational appropriations</SPAN></P>
<P class="p757 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">–</SPAN><SPAN class="ft167">The proposal/initiative does not require the use of operational appropriations</SPAN></P>
<P class="p123 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">–</SPAN><SPAN class="ft203">: </SPAN>The proposal/initiative requires the use of operational appropriations, as explained below:</P>
<P class="p65 ft1">The specific objectives of the proposal are outlined under section 1.4.2. The main type of output that EBA is expected to produce using the requested resources is binding technical standards (BTS). <SPAN class="ft204">The proposals require EBA to develop some 55 BTS with 60% of them due in 2013. </SPAN>However, due to the nature of the initiative the below table cannot be filled out as it is not possible to attribute BTS to a single specific objective, since - as a rule - one BTS contributes to the achievement of multiple specific objectives simultaneously. For instance, a BTS on consistent application of deductions from the regulatory capital would contribute to i) enhancing bank risk management; ii) preventing regulatory arbitrage opportunities; iii) enhancing legal clarity; iv) enhancing level playing field; and v) enhancing supervisory cooperation and convergence.</P>
</DIV>

<P class="p842 ft172">For miscellaneous assigned revenue, specify the budget expenditure line(s) affected.</P>
<P class="p843 ft172">Specify the method for calculating the impact on revenue.</P>
<P class="p844 ft196"><SPAN class="ft48">19</SPAN><SPAN class="ft236">As regards traditional own resources (customs duties, sugar levies), the amounts indicated must be net amounts, i.e. gross amounts after deduction of 25% for collection costs.</SPAN></P>

<P class="p522 ft1">Annex to Legislative Financial Statement for proposal for regulation on prudential requirements for credit institutions and investment firms and for proposal for directive on the taking up and pursuit of the business of credit institutions and the prudential supervision of credit institutions and investment firms</P>
<P class="p651 ft2">Applied methodology and main underlying assumptions</P>
<P class="p46 ft1">The costs related to tasks to be carried out by EBA stemming from the two proposals have been estimated for staff expenditure (Title 1), in conformity with the cost classification in the EBA draft budget for 2012 submitted to the Commission.</P>
<P class="p48 ft1">The two proposals of the Commission include provisions for EBA to develop some 55 sets of new binding technical standards (BTS) that should ensure that provisions of highly technical nature are consistently implemented across the EU.<SPAN class="ft58">20 </SPAN>According to the proposals, EBA is expected to deliver some 60% of the new BTS in 2013. To meet this goal, increase in staffing level is required already starting with 2013. As regards the nature of positions, the successful and timely delivery of new BTS will require, in particular, additional policy, legal and impact assessment officers.</P>
<P class="p548 ft1">Based on the estimates of the Commission services and EBA, the following assumptions were applied to assess the impact on number of FTEs required to develop BTS related to the two proposals:</P>
<P class="p16 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">–</SPAN><SPAN class="ft145">One policy officer drafts 2 BTS of average complexity per year; this implies that 17 policy officers are needed for 2013;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p218 ft4"><SPAN class="ft1">–</SPAN><SPAN class="ft237">One impact assessment officer is needed for 8 BTS processes; this implies that 4 impact assessment officers are needed for 2013;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p486 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">–</SPAN><SPAN class="ft145">One legal officer is needed to draft 5 BTS; this implies that 7 legal officers are needed for 2013;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p217 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">–</SPAN><SPAN class="ft145">Two additional support FTEs are needed to provide support to the above positions on a daily basis.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p511 ft1">Hence, delivery of BTS that are falling due in 2013 requires 30 FTEs. According to EBA, by the end of 2011, there will be 14 experts working on BTS. In anticipation of the increase in <NOBR>BTS-related</NOBR> workload, in its draft budget for 2012 submitted to the Commission, EBA already requested additional 22 FTEs, of which 7 are earmarked for the work on BTS.<SPAN class="ft58">21 </SPAN>In its submission of draft budget for 2012,</P>
<P class="p846 ft172"><SPAN class="ft48">20</SPAN><SPAN class="ft238">Since EBA is a body with highly specialised expertise, it was empowered to develop BTS in response to a need to introduce an effective instrument to establish harmonised regulatory technical standards in EU banking legislation to ensure, also through a single rulebook, a level playing field and adequate protection of depositors, investors and consumers across the Union. To this end, EBA prepares draft regulatory technical standards in areas defined by Union law, which do not involve policy choices, and which the Commission later endorses by means of delegated acts pursuant to Article 290 TFEU in order to give them binding legal effect. Before submitting draft BTS to the Commission, EBA has to conduct extensive preparatory work which includes consulting on draft BTS with interested parties and providing such parties with a reasonable opportunity to comment on proposed measures; carrying out regulatory impact assessments; legal drafting and other tasks.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p847 ft158"><SPAN class="ft48">21</SPAN><SPAN class="ft239">Other positions requested by EBA in the draft budget for 2012 are attributed to the expected increase in the workload of its oversight and operations departments. The request for an increase in other positions is linked to the evidence on resource utilisation emerging in the course of the first year of operation of EBA, and is geared towards ensuring the</SPAN></P>
<P class="p848 ft1">227</P>
</DIV>
<DIV id="page_229">
<DIV id="dimg1">
<INGENBILD zsrc="GZB6452229x1.jpg/" id="img1">
</DIV>


<P class="p522 ft1">EBA did not include a request for the remaining 9 FTEs needed because it was not aware of the number of BTS that it would be asked to develop by the two proposals. These positions, however, will be included in the forthcoming annual budget requests of EBA.</P>
<P class="p637 ft1">Other assumptions:</P>
<P class="p849 ft1"><SPAN class="ft39">-</SPAN><SPAN class="ft55">based on the distribution of FTEs in 2012 draft budget, additional 9 FTEs are assumed to be comprised of 7 temporary agents (79%), 1 seconded national expert (14%) and 1 contractual agent (7%);</SPAN></P>
<P class="p850 ft1"><SPAN class="ft39">-</SPAN><SPAN class="ft55">average annual salary costs for different categories of personnel are based on DG BUDG guidance;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p851 ft1"><SPAN class="ft39">-</SPAN><SPAN class="ft55">salary weighting coefficient for London of 1.344;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p852 ft1"><SPAN class="ft39">-</SPAN><SPAN class="ft55">training costs assumed at 1,000 per FTE per year;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p727 ft1"><SPAN class="ft39">-</SPAN><SPAN class="ft55">mission costs of 9,700, estimated based on 2012 draft budget for missions per average FTE;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p853 ft1"><SPAN class="ft39">-</SPAN><NOBR><SPAN class="ft55">recruiting-related</SPAN></NOBR> costs (travel, hotel, medical examinations, installation and other allowances, removal costs, etc) of 27,700, estimated based on 2012 draft budget for recruiting per position to be filled in.</P>
<P class="p854 ft1">It was assumed that the workload behind the above increase in FTEs will be maintained in 2014 onwards, and is linked, in part, to amending the already developed BTS and, in part, to preparing the remaining 40% of BTS under the two legislative proposals and under other forthcoming legislative proposals in the area of banking regulation.</P>
<P class="p48 ft1">The method of calculating the increase in the required budget for the next three years is presented in more detail in table below. The calculation reflects the fact that that the Community budget funds 40% of the costs.</P>
<P class="p855 ft158">effective execution of EBA's tasks with respect to breaches of law, presence in colleges of supervisors, consumer dimension, international dimension and other areas.</P>
<P class="p848 ft1">228</P>
</DIV>
